text:
Behind the location at the Cheshire Inn on western side of Forest Park, this is probably the most unique Starbucks in St. Louis. Service is quick, the staff are personable (even when slammed under the morning rush) and the atmosphere is a little less corporate in feel. There's little mistaking that you're in a Starbucks when you step in the door, but it's also distinctly the Central West End Starbucks.

Skim the reviews (or Google Maps) and you'll find just about all that you need to know for a great visit to this walkable store.

There's no dedicated parking lot or pickup spot, but there a few sturdier places to lock up a bike on the block. (Drivers do have options though. There's a public garage above the Schlafly Library on Euclid and metered parking along the street. Free street parking is often available to the east of the shop on Maryland Ave and there's a paid parking lot across the street too).

There's no drive-thru, but mobile orders are usually accepted. The location isn't that large, but does have a good mix of semi-communal seating, small tables, sidewalk seating and a couple of more comfortable chairs.

If there's really any complaint with the store, it's the minor irritation of its tendency to sell out of products, whether it's Blonde Roast, breakfast sandwiches or Nitro Cold Brew (each of which have been unavailable at least once during my random stops in over the past year). I've never had that affect an app order but, if you have your mind set on a particular item, it's probably best to order ahead.
name: Starbucks
categories: Food, Restaurants, Coffee & Tea

text:
I love this home town cooking breakfast spot!

Everyone that works here is so nice and they love their homemade hot sauce. 

All of us went for the sweet side of breakfast and we weren't disappointed. The waffles were perfect, the pancakes were insane and the French toast was amazing!

Next time, we're going for savory and we're using some of their home made hot sauce. 
The apple jalapeÃ±o was oddly delicious!
name: Mauki's Bakery & Country Store

text: Despite Proximity to Coffee Cartel, this starbucks is always pretty crowded inside. Can usually find a seat fairly easy outside, but inside is high demand and cramped. Great service though, they do well given the space.
name: Starbucks
categories: Food, Restaurants, Coffee & Tea

text:
With some of the lackluster service at the surrounding restaurants and cafes, I have to give Starbucks props for cranking out the drinks in a timely, efficient, and customer oriented manner. Something that can't be said (at least not all three) of the surrounding restaurants I tried while in St. Louis.

This Starbucks is fairly large for being centrally located in the Central West End, It also has seating in a sun room that is probably only open during the warmer months. Perfect for enjoying the outdoor music and other festivities that always seem to be happening in the neighborhood.

4 stars for service.
name: Starbucks
categories: Food, Restaurants, Coffee & Tea

text: I haven't even finished eating yet and I'm writing a review. This place is incredible. Friendly little neighborhood shop that I'll probably spend $100 on bakery items before I leave. It all looks that good. Have fun with the staff when you come in. They're like family and I've only known them ten minutes. What a great place.

text:
Probably my best food truck experience to date.  Ordered the cuban sandwich and was met with the seemingly ubiquitous, "fries?"  Knowing I'm in food truck land and upsells for sides can add $5-7 to my bill, I politely said no thanks.
  I did ask for extra pickles on the sandwich and heard the lady at the window say mucho something which started a bit of an argument in the truck.  I going to guess the sandwiches are prepped ahead with little ability to alter.(Especially since mine seemed standard after recieving) Figuring my sandwich probably wouldnt be enough I also ordered 2 beef empanadas.

Order was prepared quickly, maybe 5 minutes.  When I opened my bag, it had fries.  Apparently, the sandwich comes with a side item and my worry of an upsell was only an assumption I wanted fries.    Now Im curious what other sides the have available.

This was all to-go btw.  When I got home sandwich (missing extra pickles) was larger than expected.  Too often food truck portions are on the small side.  This was easily good for 2 people.  Fries, nice unexpected bonus, and the beef empanadas were really, really good.  Even after 1 shot grease all over my leg.  My fault for not eating at the table.  Had this not been 15 minutes after getting my food, it would have been hot, and yes it could have ruined clothing.  But I strangely without a napkin near I found myself licking it off in beefy greasy bliss.

Looking forward to the other half sandwich tonight AND the next opportunity I have to order from this truck.  Keep up the good work.
name: Havana's Cuisine

text: The owner and staff at this place were so nice! Despite being busy the owner took time to talk to folks. I suggest that when you walk in immediately go to the the display of bakery items - in the case and on the counter. Pick what you want before someone else does!! Ha. I scooped up peach cobbler bread and so happy that I did. It's delicious. I was there with a group of 6-7 friends for breakfast. One guy ordered the biscuits and gravy. OMG talk about huge! It easily could have fed 4 people. I had a little taste and it was great. Their breakfast burritos were also quite large. I myself ordered the french toast with a side of sausage. My french toast was a little too dry for me but my friend who also got it said she loved it. The sausage was excellent! This place is not super crowded convenient for us but we will return!

text:
I've been a fan of Havana's Cuisine since they had a food truck, now that they have a brick and mortar location I'm ecstatic that I can get Cuban food any time. 

I'm from Miami (the 305) and I grew up with Cuban food in my home so I know the real deal when I taste it and oh brother, this is it!

They always offer a nice selection of sandwiches with the Tampa Cuban being my favorite. They also have a nice selection of hot plates, today I got the roasted pork with white rice, black beans, and sweet plantains. Totally delicious and worth the drive from St Charles to downtown STL. 

And BTW, the servings are huge, I always get two meals out of one order. Also, the flan is the best in Missouri. 

Enjoy!
name: Havana's Cuisine

text:
I have been craving Cuban food in St. Louis. I heard about this place and how they had a spot at the Soulard Farmers Market (and they recently opened a food truck), so I decided to check them out. They did not disappoint!

The line was pretty long, but it gave me time to figure out what I wanted. I got the chicken and yellow rice as my lunch and the portion was HUGE. It was at least 3 meals worth of food and only for $7! I also got a beef croquetta, maduros, and a guava pastry. The guava pastry was so good and the croquetta had the perfect seasoning. I think I waited too long to eat the maduros, but if I had them fresh I'm sure they would have been delicious. 

The owners are originally from Havana, Cuba and moved to St. Louis a few years ago because their daughter is really involved in chess. Go support them because their flavors are what this city has been missing!
name: Havana's Cuisine

text:
Full disclosure, I did NOT visit the actual Mauki's Bakery & Country Store... BUT I did visit their stall at the Soulard Farmers Market in Saint Louis! The man working there was extremely helpful, friendly & talkative,  and a real salesman! He talked up Mauki's to all who approached and encouraged each person to visit Mauki's in person to eat there. I left with a menu in hand and the selections looked wonderful on paper.

My time and schedule unfortunately didn't allow for a visit, but I was able to bring home some fresh bread from their Farmer's Market stall - and I was very impressed with the  flavor, freshness, and texture. A few stalls down the way, a worker saw me carrying my tin of Mauki's bread and he shouted out (with a real genuine sense of pride "hey you've got some of my bread there, I baked that!" That's the sort of worker spirit that makes you conclude that there's something truly special going on, & that it's worth checking out.

So the bread I selected was Cranberry Orange. There are many other flavors available. Moist & flavorful, & travelled quite well back to Ohio. Reasonably priced. I'm looking forward to returning to Saint Louis at some point in the future, & hope an in person visit to Mauki's will be possible. Great bread!
name: Mauki's Bakery & Country Store

text:
Love Cane's. They're the In-N-Out of the Deep South and St. Louis is fortunate to have several outlets.

For me the sign of a quality fast-casual food is just how quickly it works through my body. I can wreck a Caniac Combo (six fingers) with two sauces and two Texas Toasts and a Sweet Tea in a few minutes. Without fail, driving home the stomach starts to gurgle - it's either clench or be clenched all the way home. Once I had to pull over to a Mickey D's to use their rest room, while the men's stalls were all full I had to duck into the lady's room or face the consequences of some seriously delicious and addictive chicken.

Viva la Cane's!
name: Raising Cane's Chicken Fingers

text: This place is quickly becoming one of my favorite places to go.  The chicken fingers have this phenomenal breading that is light but also very crispy.  The meat is cooked to perfection and very juicy.  I of course dip them in the Canes sauce which is one of my favorite dipping sauces of all time. The side of crinkle fries that comes with the basket just compliments the meal.  I dip those in the Cane sauce also!  The drink choice to  wash it all down is their fresh brewed sweet tea which I consider right up there with the very best I've had.  The best part about this chicken place is a consistent product.  The food baskets are always piping hot and the food is excellent.  I would highly recommend Raising Canes to everyone!
name: Raising Cane's Chicken Fingers

text: As a lover of Chik-Fil-A it was hard for me to venture out and try another fast food chicken place. However I have a found a new love in Raising Canes! Their service is fast and their employees are friendly. The menu options are limited but what more could you want than good chicken and fries? The chicken is tender with a crispy breading, the fries are never soggy, and it comes with a buttery Texas toast to finish off the meal. But let's talk about the Cane's sauce....I can't get away with not ordering extra which they will charge you for and I will happily pay. The tangy delicious sauce I use with both the chicken and the fries. The caniac meal with six chicken fingers, fries, and a 32oz drink is my husband and my go to meal to share when we're on the go.
name: Raising Cane's Chicken Fingers

text:
Don't Forget To Kiss The Cook :

I don't usually write reviews about fast food restaurants BUT when one of the employees go above and beyond ...it's time to let the boss know you have a Fantastic Employee...
Her name is Amanda ...After finishing our meal we moved the empty baskets with our trash at the edge of the table , one of the girls working there walked by three times and never once asked ... Could I take this away for you? 
Amanda would walk around the restaurant and pick up trash clean tables and talk to customers... She is a very friendly girl ...and treats her job as if she owns the restaurant...
We are not going to mention the girls name who walked by and left the trash we just want her boss to know she is a FANTASTIC EMPLOYEE...

We both agreed the fried chicken is very good and yes we will be back...
THANK YOU Amanda for talking and joking around with us.
You made lunch today a real enjoyment ....

P.S. 
To Amanda's boss ..... She deserves a raise....
( LOL i told her i would say that )
name: Raising Cane's Chicken Fingers

text: Starting off with the service, it was great and super friendly! Sushi was very good, fresh and flavorful. The Thai Green Curry was also exceptional. But don't get this mixed up with St. Louis Chinese food. I ordered a chicken fried rice and chicken Chow Mein, it was bland flavorless and was just like eating white rice with boiled chicken and steamed veggies. Now for the Chow Mein, it was like eating boiled spaghetti noodles with boiled veggies absolutely no flavor or color on the noodles. Same goes with the rice, neither had flavor or color from the wok. If you go here stick with the Thai food and sushi, if you want St. Louis style Chinese food go to lucky China up the street next to Pink Galleon.
name: Thai Asian Cuisine

text: I ordered goat vindaloo. On the phone, when she was reviewing my order, she said "lamb vindaloo". I said, "No, goat vindaloo". I go to pick it up, and the receipt says "mutton vindaloo".  I figured, oh well, I like lamb anyway. I ordered it extra spicy. Got it home and started eating. It tastes like tomato sauce with heat and that's it. It's so tangy I can barely eat it. What's worse, my first real bites of the meat were straight hard cartilage. The rice is bland and not aromatic at all. The garlic naan has no flavor whatsoever. Just bread with some garlic on it. This might be the worst Indian food I've ever had. And to add to all of that, the girl asked me if I wanted to contribute a cash tip. Rather than let me add it to the card. VERY UNIMPRESSED with this place and will not return.
name: Bawarchi

text:
I'm always impressed by the management and staff at the Maplewood Raising Cane's. This is my husband's most frequently-visited Cane's location, and each time we (or he) goes they are always friendly, and the food is hot and fresh. 

If there ever is a forgotten item, it's easy to call up and let them know. They are always happy to fix it, and often will comp you your next meal. Such wonderful customer service!

If you order their Naked Tenders, you'll be asked to wait in a parking spot since they are made fresh. It's never too long of a wait, and quite a few times the staff has thrown in an extra tender or two for the wait. Thoughtful and always appreciated! 

Thanks so much, Maplewood Raising Cane's staff, for your excellent service! You all are great and appreciated!
name: Raising Cane's Chicken Fingers

text:
Having been to Bawarchi locations throughout the country, I'm quite familiar and happy with their biryani.  That being said, I stopped in to order some chicken biryani to-go.

Since I knew what I wanted I didn't look at the menu.
I also ordered a chili-paneer.

The biryani was standard and didn't disappoint.  It came with a leg, thigh and breast piece.  I was happy to see substantial portions of meat.  

I was however very disappointed by the chili paneer.   The paneer itself was cooked through, but was doused in marinara sauce- obviously not Indian/Pakistani at all.  The dish was altogether awful.

The biryani gets four stars, and the chili paneer gets two stars at most.  I'll be back for the biryani and probably try the chicken 65 next time, so a follow-up review is pending.
name: Bawarchi

text: I have to say, this place is far and away the best, most authentic Thai food I've ever eaten and I eat Thai cuisine weekly. A true hidden gem in STL and worth whatever drive you have to make to get here. For our first trip, we were conservative and ordered pot stickers, Viet Pho, Tom Kai soup, wonton soup, spicy basil beef, and General Tso with fried rice. There was literally nothing left and we were all STUFFED. The flavor, freshness, everything about our meal was perfect. We will be back to explore the curry side of the menu as well as everything else. The waitress and cook were warm and welcoming and on top of everything we needed. We were truly blown away and are still talking about how great everything was. They no longer offer sushi but it wasn't worth mentioning with how good everything was.
name: Thai Asian Cuisine

text:
I'm pretty impressed with this spot! It's newly opened in my old Chinese takeout location, and I have to say - these new folks are doing great! 

The food is really good. It's always hot, very fresh, and portion size is enough for multiple meals. Over several visits I've tried spring rolls, sesame chicken, chicken fried rice, broccoli and beef, cashew chicken, veggie stir fry, and steamed veggies, among other things. I love the quality of the food.

The service is excellent! On the two rare occasions I waited a short time for my food, the kind server gave me a free drink - some kind of delicious Thai milk and tea combo mystery drink. I have no idea what I was drinking, but it was so good! 

They are offering curb side pick up in the pandemic, and I'll definitely keep coming back!
name: Thai Asian Cuisine

text:
Mysore Bonda, Mirchi Bajji and Tea. These were the 3 items we ordered since we had to drive back for 4 hrs we placed order for to go. 
I didn't checked the reviews as the name was familiar. But it was the opposite.  The Mirchi bajjis they were tasteless.  There was no salt, no spice at all.  They didn't even have the order with some sliced onions, lemon or chaat masala sprinkled.  The flour used didn't seemed besan but instead corn flour I guess.  They basically dipped the green peppers in plain flour without even salt and gave it to us. I was very disappointed. Will give just 1 star to Mirchi bajjis.  The name ' Bawarchi' had been not satisfied.  
Second comes to tea. We placed order for Masala tea from the menu , but they said they don't have it.  So we went for plain tea - and don't ask me about it- they used milk powder instead of milk.  It was just like hot water. 
1 star for tea as well.
And lastly comes the Mysore Bonda.  This was little better than the above two. But not the best.  I will give a 2.5 for Mysore Bonda.

My suggestion - people visiting St. Louis please don't go for the name for any restaurant. Definitely not worth it unless you don't have any other option.
name: Bawarchi

text: This place is a must try! We walked in shortly before they closed. The waitress was very friendly and accommodating. We got the papaya salad to start off. It was crisp, fresh, and perfect. Next we got the Caterpillar sushi roll. We saw it being made fresh behind the counter! The portion was large for the price and very yummy. Lastly, we got the red curry. It was packed with veggies and plenty of meat. They allow you to pick spice level from 1-5 which we really liked- we like our food spicy! There are so many options on the menu, there's something for everyone. And given our experience, I'm sure everything will be fresh and phenomenal!

text:
First time going to Bawarchi. I got chicken sashi  korma and Hyderabad Chicken Curry. I often get 2 entrees to have the flavor variety and leftovers.  While the sauces tasted good and as ordered, I was disappointed at how little chicken there was in the container- at least 30-40% less than I would have expected.  

I had so much sauce left over that I considered adding cooked chicken to make the full meal out of it. 

I probably won't go back, but the place was clean,  the staff wore masks and I appreciated the efforts.  A sign at the door indicated 'no mask, no service' which is a good thing in my opinion.

The menu was extensive with lots of unique options in comparison to other local Indian restaurants.  

If there had been more protein in the order to balance the meal, I would very likely go back.
name: Bawarchi

text: Fast, friendly, and super attentive to people's needs. attributes.Ambience: {'touristy': False, 'hipster': False, 'romantic': False, 'divey': False, 'intimate': False, 'trendy': False, 'upscale': False, 'classy': False, 'casual': False}

categories: Thai, Restaurants

text:
Delicious, amazing Thai food. Perfect service and large selection of authentic dishes. I was impressed by their extremely clean and tastefully decorated dining area, which is not common in most strip mall restaurants. First, the wonderful aromas of grilled meats, fresh herbs, and spices that hits you when you walk in is intoxicating! The second we walked in we were immediately welcomed by several employees in a warm fashion. I chose the Thai vegetable stir fry with beef and my companion chose the green curry with pork. I also got a papaya salad and Tom Kha soup(chicken, lemon grass, coconut milk) as those are my tester for the quality of Thai food. I have found a new favorite Thai spot!! A delicious Tom Kha arrived in a cute little crock, full to the brim with savory herbaceous broth. It was piping hot and heavy on the fish sauce, but mild on spice. I will ask for Thai spicy next time. [It had so many pieces of lemon grass and galangal(wonderful citrus flavor) in it though, which made it hard to eat. They are woody and pretty inedible and should be removed from the soup IMO before serving like bay leaves, cloves, etc. but I counted at least fifteen pieces in my small bowl. Just a small complaint, because the soup itself was excellent]
Papaya salad: best I have had in MO. Came in a huge portion with tomatoes, fried cashews, and an amazing sweet, spicy, sour sauce with plenty of limes for squeezing! yay! Perfect.

Stir fry: huge portion, delicious broccoli, carrots, mushrooms, zucchini-meh, peppers, cabbage and baby corn. Savory gingery brothy sauce, perfectly seasoned beef which was pretty tender. I would get it again with just veg!

Green curry: sweet, spicy, very rich, very good. Yum, plus great roast pork. 

Service was spot on, gorgeous plating, food came out very quickly at busy lunch time, check brought quickly, boxes offered without asking, and server answered all my questions perfectly and was super helpful. She recommended to say Thai spicy so they know I like my food very spicy next time. I cant wait to go again!
name: Thai Asian Cuisine

attributes.Ambience: {'touristy': False, 'hipster': False, 'romantic': False, 'divey': False, 'intimate': False, 'trendy': False, 'upscale': False, 'classy': False, 'casual': False}

text:
Bawarchi is my favorite Indian restaurant in St. Louis. I've been going there regularly for almost a year now. The dosas are very authentic and there are plenty of other South Indian options that are hard to find in other Indian restaurants in this area.

Believe it or not, Indian cuisine is different in every state of India (and all of it is amazing). So, if you find the food different here compared to another Indian restaurant, that's probably why. 

Try the biriyanis, kothu parotta, chola bature or any of the dosas, you won't be disappointed. Don't just stick to the meat options, Indian vegetarian dishes have a lot of flavor, unlike most other cuisines.

In the age of freezer to microwave cooking it's nice to see a restaurant that makes amazing dishes from scratch with plenty of options for vegetarians. I cannot wait for my next dosa.
name: Bawarchi

text:
I'm glad I found this place tucked into the strip mall of businesses while I was stuck in one of the many nearby hotels for work travel.

It's a very small place, but is decorated nicely and had enough seating for the sparse crowd that sat down to eat on the weekday night I was here. Based on the number of phone calls they got and people coming in to get bags of food, they certainly seem to have a healthy flow of to-go business. The lady working the front wore quite a few hats so she was very busy, but she was also very nice and welcoming. Paper menus were available at the counter and it was seat yourself. You also pay at the counter, and make sure you specifically ask for a copy of the receipt if you need one.

The menu was massive and was more of a Southeast Asian place than just a Thai restaurant. The servings are massive, so you're either leaving stuffed or taking home leftovers, for which they had to-go boxes for. With the small, fairly busy setting, I don't think I would recommend this for something very intimate or formal, but it was delicious food for a good price. I really enjoyed the sweet and savory yellow curry noodle soup, and I heard positive remarks about the fried rice as well. We got some fried eggrolls for an appetizer that were great, and we heard that the wide variety of egg rolls and spring rolls are wrapped fresh.

I don't think there is a lot more I would ask of a place like this, and it was certainly the best option for food in this fast food heavy part of town.
name: Thai Asian Cuisine

text:
Very clean, very polite staff. I'm not sure what most Indian dishes are (the menu doesnt really go into specific detail) so I stick to what I know: tikka masala and dal.

For an appetizer, we ordered paneer 555. We were expecting deep fried cheese. What we got was a lightly breaded, pan-fried paneer (cheese) coated with buffalo sauce and a sprinkling of cashews. It was completely unexpected, but delicious. Like boneless buffalo wings, but better.

I order the chicken tikka masala- tastes like I expected, wonderful texture and taste. It is served with rice. The portion size is huge and we took home half the order. We also ordered the Dal Makhani. It was a thinner consistency, closer to a soup. It is also served with rice. Even though we ordered it with a higher spice level, it was almost bland, or tasted like uncooked spices (like they were an afterthought).

We ordered the garlic naan- the garlic was raw and overpowering. I'd stick to the plain naan next time.

The drinks listed on the menu vs what was available differed slightly. I'm sure they are still new and trying to figure how much of everything to make based on the amount of traffic they bring in. The mango lassi was great- very creamy. The almond milk was almost like a dessert custard- very very good!
name: Bawarchi

text:
Barwachi is a chain restaurant even though there are only 3-4 of them and they are in different cities.  It feels nothing like a chain.  It still feels like a privately owned family restaurant and there is a family running it.  

I was told by many of my Indian friends that the restaurant is great but to expect Indian level spice. However, when we arrived as a group of non-Indian diners, they played it too easy on us even though several people at the table requested the food to be properly spiced.The food was great, but we hope in future that they will let us decide how much we can handle for ourselves.  The service was a little disjointed, but we enjoyed ourselves and will go back.
name: Bawarchi

text:
The food had good flavor, but it was too spicy to eat significant amounts for all three people in my group. It really made me question my spice tolerance, which I normally consider to be on the high side.

The lunch specials are a lot of food and a great price. All three in my group ordered from the lunch menu, and two of the orders came out within a few minutes. The third one took comparatively a lot longer (10-15 minutes), which was awkward. I had the chicken curry, which was also the lunch special's side curry for the day, so I didn't get an extra side with my order. Would have been nice to get the vegetarian curry in its place. It also took a long time for us to get an employee's attention to pay.

I could be convinced to come back here for lunch, but I don't think the other two in my group would tag along.
name: Bawarchi

text: Chicken chicken watcha pickin and I'll tell you when I'm picking I'm picking raising canes in Maplewood. Doesn't get much better than this. I always have really good service I love their hot sauce they're super fast at making my food and they always say the right things in the drive-through to me. Just the greeting you get when you pull up is worth it. The creativity in that building is through the roof and it's insane I never know what I'm gonna get. Well actually I do because they only have like five things on the menu. Their bread is always so soft I don't know how the hell they do it. Plus they're open super late so I go after I work out at the gym and it makes me feel like I really didn't just work out because I put the way back on but life is about consistency and I'm just fine with that. They would never let me down and I spent so much money there I literally go there every week. I get this plays five stars and I would give it six if I could. My boyfriend loves the caniac combo. I even always take the survey so I get free canes for a year but I've never gotten it so if the owner is seeing this please give me something.

text:
Tried this place for the first time tonight. I called in a carry out order and my order was ready in 5 min! I ordered the Thai basil fried rice, with veggies instead of meat. It was really good. The whole dish, but especially the veggies, was so fresh and flavorful, and cooked to perfection! I also ordered an appetizer of Vietnamese egg rolls. They were good too. My food was still steaming hot when I got home. This place really pays attention to detail, even the presentation of my carry out order was impressive with ornately placed garnish.

My only complaint is I felt the price was a little high. $20 for an app and fried rice. I'll pay the price for now because this place is new and I want it to succeed, but as it becomes busier, I hope they drop the prices a little.
name: Thai Asian Cuisine

text:
The bawarchi of bawarchi needs some cooking classes. I start by saying "Indian food is not always spicy and hot" , it's a myth that Indian food is spicy and the food here was spicy and no good at all. The food served here can kill you if you can't handle spices , not for light hearted ones :) . We got a lot of Togo yesterday and had to throw off everything as they weren't eatable , no taste just chilli and more chilli. The worst thing a chef can do is add raw chilli powder to food without sautÃ©ing the powder which makes it harmful to eat and we could taste that in the chilli paneer, the worst ever chilo I Paneer I ate ever in my life and I come
From the city where from the dish originates.The biriyanis were super spicy and no one in the group was able to eat and preferred eating some frozen stuff rather than the Togo. All in all ... the worst Indian food we ever ate in Saint Louis.
name: Bawarchi

text: Some of the BEST authentic Thai food we've eaten in St. Louis, and the chef (and her server) were very accommodating with our order (party of 6 but sharing/ family style). Server came to check on us and chat with us often; Chef came between making appetizers and entrees and after she finished cooking. We ordered Chicken Satay and Tod Mun (fish cakes) for appetizers. For entrees we ordered Som Tum (Green papaya salad), Pad See Ew noodles, *Laard Naa noodles, Red curry with Tofu for the vegetarian, Basil Salmon, and Ginger sauce Grouper. Tod Mun came out first (very quickly). Next out was Green Papaya salad, and it was a good size salad. I had requested Mild spiciness but it was on the more spicy end, other wise good. I'll ask for not spicy next time. Next out was Red curry with Tofu, to which we had asked to add pineapples. This was also on the more spicy end (server had not asked spice level). Maybe because I'm Thai, my husband and his parents are Indian, she assumed we all can handle spicy. Chicken Satay finally came out, and it was worth the wait -- very juicy & tender, well spiced. Next out came Grouper and Salmon dishes. While they were both, good, the portion size was small considering the price, so we likely won't order those again. Next out was Pad See Ew noodles, and last was Laard Naa noodles, which was *not on the menu*, but my daughter really wanted it and asked the server. Of course the chef could make it -- and it was delicious so she should add to her menu! Both noodles were large portions, with plenty of veggies which most other Thai restaurants do  NOT give enough of. We will be back to order Chicken Satay and noodles again, esp. since other Thai restaurant swe've been to in St Louis area have not had Laard Naa on the menu.
name: Thai Asian Cuisine

text: Thai Asian cuisine is a new Thai restaurant in a strip mall in South County at the corner of Butler Hill Road and Highway 55. The food is delicious, but spicy. If you are from Thailand, you will probably love it. If you are American, it may be hotter than what you are used to.They do allow you to choose spice level, but if you are picky, I would suggest to spice down. It does not translate the same as if you are ordering at a Thai restaurant on by people who have been here for a while.There is also a language barrier as others have suggested, so I would not suggest substitutes and special requests. But, you can't go to an ethnic restaurant and expect everybody to speak perfect English. It's unreasonable to think that will happen.  Great food and nice owners .  Nice ambience. Nice owners.  I'll be back.
name: Thai Asian Cuisine

text: We are a Thai food family for sure and I generally don't rate all the Thai places I go to because, well you know. This place started off with good veggie egg rolls, and quick to deliver food right behind it. I had the veggie Thai and everyone else went Thai fried rice this round and no complaints at all. Very tasty but if I could give one good order of advice, it's this, up your spice level one level here because anything less you won't have any spice. If you don't like spice at all, why are you eating Thai food at all.  Pleasant staff, quick delivery, good food. Definitely worth the visit.

text:
ABSOLUTELY INCREDIBLE FOOD!!! Cannot stress enough how perfectly, completely, utterly delicious the food is here. 

I was interested by the fact that there were no descriptions or photos on the menu. I took that as a good sign that people who know Indian food eat here.  I confess I googled the dish I ultimately ordered to make sure I was ordering what I thought I was.  

The service was hampered a little by a language barrier.  But I'm good with that. We all managed just fine.

I recommend this place. I also noticed a lot of Grub Hub and take out orders ready to go by the hostess station.  So if you're not down for a sit down meal, they are definitely set up for takeout.

text: I had always grown up with my family telling me, "Don't eat sushi!  It's raw fish!  It's disgusting!"  Then I left St. Louis and moved to Miami for several years, and if you've ever lived there, you're eventually going to try sushi.  It's inevitable.  It became my favorite food, instantly, toppling pizza from its perch (which I still love, but not as much as sushi.).  Back in St. Louis, you'd think it'd be hard to find decent sushi in a city in the almost exact center of the U. S. and you'd be right, I usually settle for okay, because it still tastes good and okay sushi is better than no sushi.  There is a place I frequent on Lemay Ferry that has really good sushi, but I hate driving, so I always look for somewhere closer.  Then this Thai restaurant opened in the Schnucks plaza on Butler Hill about three months ago.  For Christmas, I wanted sushi.  I know this is a Thai restaurant, but it has a sushi bar, I see it every time I walk to Schnucks.  So today on Christmas Eve, I went there and got spicy tuna rolls and a bit of salmon sashimi.  I was likely their first customer.  Not only are they as good as the other place, but they actually give you a substantial portion of sashimi.  The other place only gives you one piece.  Now, sooner or later, I'm going to have to try the Thai food because that's actually what they specialize in.
name: Thai Asian Cuisine

text: We went to bawarchi after my father and I discovered that the Steak and Shake nearby had closed down and we were still craving red meat so we decided to go to bawarchi. The ambience and the service were average. However, the biryani wasn't good at all. We got the Hyderabadi Mutton biryani and the biryani smelt bad, tasted bad and did not sit well at all. I felt sick the day after too. The only redeeming thing was the curry that goes on top of the biryani. Their curry is delicious. My dad however told me that he had much better experiences with this restaurant. But because I had a bad experience, my review is just as harsh.

text:
Solid neighborhood bar. plastic dartboard, friendly patrons, and just a nice place to grab a burger and relax on the street. 
Beers a fairly cheap ($3 - $4) Burgers with fries run about $6 - $8. Not too much on the menu, burgers, wings, bar food, but bar food done well.

text: This establishment severely lacks the necessary payment options and hospitality to regain my business! When I first started ordering from Great Wall the food was fresh,  hot, and delicious and nearly payment option was accepted. They're customer service was excellent and beyond compare, but in recent year they have become rude and it seems that despite having sufficient funds to cover my order and no matter which card I give them it's always denied. I even confronted the employee about it and she rudely stated that its my problem and my fault because I am the only customer that they have a problem with. The last few times I've had cash and ordered online from them I waited for over an hour and then had to call to ask where my order was. Despite giving them my order confirmation number and everything to varify that I had indeed place an online order the associate rudely exclaimed, "sorry you no make order!" Understanding that its possible that system issues could be to blame I agreed to place my order over the phone and had to wait yet again nearly another hour before my food arrived and it was not fresh! It had tasted absolutely aweful! So my lesson learned avoid Great Wall at all cost! This place is not worth your time, money, or fustration!
name: Great Wall

text: So disappointed. I've been here before and the food was not bad. Tonight, not so much. I got the house special fried rice, small order of crab Rangoon and sweet and sour chicken. The fried rice was a little dried out but was decent. The sweet and sour chicken was terrible. The box that held the white rice weighed more than the box with the chicken in it (and was half the size of the chicken box). This was my first red flag. When I bit into the "chicken" it was 80% breading and 20% chicken. I had to pull significant amounts of breading off to even find a small piece of chicken to eat. At this point I was just hoping the crab Rangoon was good since I remembered it being pretty good last time. I honestly don't even know how but the filling almost tasted spongey. It was such a weird texture and with very little flavor I couldn't eat it. Honestly, the only reason I am giving 2 stars is because of the good experience of my last visit, but I know I will not be returning again to spend over $20 on food I can't even eat.
name: Great Wall

text:
This is a bar with a limited menu of standard bar food. 
After settling in and a little more research I realized I wasn't at Krieger's Sports Bar and Grill, which once had multiple locations in St. Louis and I thought still did. 
No, I was at Krueger's Bar. There's no "and grill" in the name: The food menu includes  appetizers, a few sandwiches, a couple of burgers, and some salads. 
I ordered the Poor Boy sandwich. 
The hoagie bread was very good: The rest looked like store-bought slices of cheese and deli meats with an iceberg lettuce leaf placed on top. Nothing remarkable. 
I didn't need condiments, which was good because halfway through the sandwich I was asked if I wanted mayonnaise. 
(Except for that the service was quick and attentive.)
The lunch basket included a pickle slice, a pepper, and a bag of Lay's potato chips (option: fries or potato salad). So, basically, I got table service that was very good for pretty much what I could have picked up at a nearby convenience store. 
At 12:30 there were only two other small lunch parties. Four or five regulars came in at 1. 
Patio seating available and there's a shared side parking lot with coin meters.
name: Krueger's Bar

text: My final review today after the worse excuse for food imaginable. 2 chicken and broccoli and wings. I knew I was taking a chance on the wings, and I lost. They were not cooked fresh. I believe they were frozen, as they were so overcooked and tough, just like the previous time I ordered them. Hardly eatable. Some of the chicken in the broccoli dish were also very tough. I threw out over half of it. This place claims to use only fresh ingredients. Impossible. If they just got better beef and chicken, this place would flourish, but they won't do that. In over 35 years in St. Louis, I've only found one Chinese place with tender beef and they closed a long time ago. I will not be ordering from this place again.

text: We LOVE Roberto's! They have the best pizza (crispy thin crust with lots of toppings), salads (loaded with cheese), buffalo chicken strips, fried chicken, cheese burgers, garlic cheese bread, I could go on & on. I highly recommend especially if you are a thin crust pizza lover. Oh one more thing, they have crushed ice! Hello, does it get better than that?

text:
As the other review stated, this pizza is LEGIT.  Absolutely fantastic!  Our Pizza had a delightful fresh crispy thin crust and was lightly sauced (the way my wife likes it).  The italian sausage was a flavorful link sausage which had been it into slices.  The cheese tasted like some sort of blend, predominantly provel; we loved it.  This is St Louis Style Pizza at its best.  

Our lasagna, on the other hand, was forgettable. It was a bit loose and there wasn't much ricotta or other yumminess. It was mostly meat sauce and noodles, with a slice of provel on top. 

I also had the dinner salad with the garlic vinaigrette. The salad was topped with a generous portion of provel and the dressing was great. I recommend it. 

The atmosphere here is strictly low rent - padded metal chairs, Formica tables, and the original tile floor from the 60's, with a half dozen tiny 19 inch TVs on the wall. The staff was very friendly and we got the impression (by eavesdropping) that this place attracts a lot of regulars. Despite the fact that we weren't regulars, we were treated very well.
name: Roberto's Italian Restaurant

text: I just don't have much luck with places that deliver. Sometimes, I feel deliveries are a good fast way for restaurants to get rid of food that's been sitting for a long time. Great Wall's 1st delivery some time ago was quite good. It's been downhill every since. Knowing their beef is tough and filled with gristle, I went with 3 chicken dishes. % wings, chicken fried rice and chicken and broccoli, the last one being the best. The 5 wings, which just 4 were eatable, were way overcooked. Very tough and the breading made the 5th one laughable. It was hard breading on a stick. The fried rice was not freshly made. Egg rolls were nice, tho. The fact it took just 15 minutes for my order to arrive at my door told me this food could not have been made fresh. Surprised and disappointed the quality here has sunk so low.
name: Great Wall

text:
I grew up in Florissant so Roberto's has an enduring place in my heart and my stomach. For the record, Flo MO was a great place to grow up. I had a happy childhood and do not need therapy. (at least not today LOL )

I'm sure that I am dating myself but I can vividly recall the days when Mullanphy Garden shopping center was a player. There was a Del Monte supermarket, a Ben Franklin five and dime and a wonderful bakery that my family visited most Sundays after church- if it was in the budget and if all of us kids had been good that week. While I am sad that those retail stalwarts no longer reside here, I am eternally grateful that Roberto's has withstood the test of time.

OK, first we must all agree that we are not talking about authentic Roma or Napoli pie here...let's just get that out of the way up front. Yes, there is a distinctly non-Italian yellowish cheese on the pie. True that bacon is not a traditional pizza topping. These facts are noted for full disclosure but are completely irrelevant IMHO. 

I know that Roberto's has a proper menu but I have experienced very little of it. It is ALL about the bacon pizza bro! GLORIOUS. When I am back in my home town visiting Mom and Dad Roberto's is a must. When I am not back in Flo I have random dreams about the delicious, kooky, non-authentic bacon pizza pie. I could eat this every single day of my life- it is pizza crack for chrissakes !
 
Maybe it is a good thing I don't live in Florissant any more...
name: Roberto's Italian Restaurant

text:
I have eaten here multiple times before I decided to review this joint and I'm giving it 5 stars for multiple reasons. I go with my significant others family, who have been coming here for over 40 years. Having people come to a location for so long is a sign that this place has withstood the times and must have a lot going for it! While the restaurant itself could use a few upgrades, I actually have become fond of the homey and familiar feel I get when I arrive to one of my favorite pizza joints. 

Some people who previously reviewed Robertos must not be familiar with St. Louis style pizza. I remember my first time eating St. Louis style pizza (over 20 years ago) I thought that they got something wrong and their style of pizza was horrific. NOW, I wouldn't have my pizza any other way!! There is no deep dish and no hand tossed. You get your good ole thin crust pizza. My favorite pizza is the shrimp pizza. Don't be fooled, I was very reserved my first time, I wasn't sure that mini shrimp on a pizza would be good. Holy smokes, I crave this pizza all the time and we drive over 30 mins out of our way to enjoy it. I highly recommend it (don't forget to ask for extra shrimp). They also have your classic pizzas, we enjoy the Garbage pizza too (their name for supreme pizza). 
We always start with toasted ravioli and garlic cheese bread. Two things you can't go wrong with either! 

The atmosphere is very casual, they have TVs around with your favorite games on and you should grab a bucket of beer while you watch. Their buckets are a great price, unlike most places I go to these days that charge an insane amount for your basic bucket! 

Staff is always kind, friendly and smiling. Yes they are always busy, but it takes some patience for a great pizza and we never wait to be seated, even though every time we go, it's a full house! Janice is the owner and usually serves us as well. Talk about an amazing woman! She is so kind and makes each time we visit, a great experience. 

I would say, don't knock it until you try it. We don't live anywhere near it and make sure to eat there at least once a month. It would be great to chow on some pizza while you watch the Blues or Cards play! It's the epitome of traditional St. Louis, now go grab some pizza and cold brews!
name: Roberto's Italian Restaurant

text:
We decided to grab a quick lunch after running errands and Krueger's was on the way home.  The only draw back was that we did not grab a quick lunch.  Although we were served our drinks and our order was taken in a timely fashion, the food took its little time getting to us. It wasn't crowded either. But I guess good food takes awhile. 

I ordered a bowl of their chili, a hamburger and onion rings.  I was starting to get hangry when the food arrived. I thought the chili would come out first but instead it came out all together.  I ordered my chili with cheese and onions on top.  The chili was delicious and the only thing I didn't like was that the onions were sliced,not diced. It made it a little hard to be a lady while eating. 

I think the cheeseburger and the onion rings were the best I've had in a long time. The burger was cooked perfectly and the onion rings put me over the top. 

Now if you want to grab a quick bite, don't come here. If you want the best bar food I have had, this is the place for you. You just have to be patient

Would I come back here?  You know I will.
name: Krueger's Bar

text: Those that know me and read my reviews know I call them as I see... or taste them, so here it goes... the good, the bad, and the ugly. First off, welcome to the new restaurant in Webster. The good news is you have time to get your sh@t together. We wanted to order Saturday night for dinner but after being open for just a week, they closed Saturday so, as their answering machine said, "they could get prepared for the next week"!!!  Really?  You chose to close for the busiest restaurant night of the week?? After only being open for a week?  Um, ok. Tonight we ordered online so I could pick it up on my way home from the gym. I show up on time only to be told by the apparent owner that online orders were being lost in their system, but if I got billed for it (so double billed) to let her know. Then, dripping wet from working out, I now had to place a new order, pay for it and wait 15 minutes for it. While waiting, I checked my bank account and of course had been double billed. I let the owner know, she checked my in store receipt, then disappeared in back without saying a word! I'll get my refund, trust me, I will, but on to the food. The Vietnamese ice coffees were both extremely bitter with seemingly no sweet creamer and nothing like we've ever had before anywhere. The fried shrimp rolls were tasty but very small, not jumbo shrimp, and came with no dipping sauce which they desperately needed. My combo vermicelli bowl was awesome but next time I'll ask for extra sauce (I chose the peanut sauce) because the sauce container is tiny. My wife got the vegan cheese rolls which were good, very small, and again no dipping sauce, which again we thought they were missing. She also had the Bahn Mi sandwich with chicken. She was disappointed and said "bland flavor and just nothing special about it".  We get the fact they are new and just opened in our hood, there are going to be screw ups and mistakes till you get things worked out, but you would think your online platform would be flawless in this day and age, or here's an idea, how about paying back the customers your system ripped off as soon as you are made aware of it or even not charge the customer for their reorder when they are standing right in front of you ??!!  Maybe they using my money to fund their crypto currency purchase? Ok, that was uncalled for and I'm being mean spirited, but I'm not taking it back. Maybe DD should contact their awesome neighbors at Sushi Station to see how to properly run an establishment in Webster. Pui would definitely set them on the right path to success. We will give them another chance because I'm sure things will get better. If they don't, some other restaurant will be filling their space in just a few short months.
name: DD Mau Vietnamese Eatery

categories: Restaurants, Vietnamese

text:
Liked the food quite a bit, prices are pricey, takes a while to get your food.  First thing I noticed was that the food costs about double what stereotypical fast food costs, even though this is essentially the same stuff - but I suppose it should be much better.  And I was already there to try it out, so...placed the order and was told it would take 5 to 10 minutes.  And it took about 10 minutes, for 3 chicken sandwiches, 2 orders of fries, and 1 order of chicken fingers.  Seemed like  long time, but then it needed to be since the chicken was cooked up fresh.  I'd rather have it fresh an hot, so not a problem for me.

The chicken on both the sandwich and the fingers was juicy and flavorful, with a well-spiced (but not chili spice),  crispy coating.  They hit the mark there.  Don't know that it was twice as good as fast food, but it was good.  The sandwiches came with 4 bread & butter pickles.  They had a good snap, but not a lot of tartness in that variety.  I think a little bit of tart would have set off well from the chicken.  And the sandwiches came with mayo on them.  Personally, I'd have preferred to put one of their own sauces on the sandwich.

Fries were thinner than a typical crinkle cut, with a good peppery spice on them.  I though the fries were top notch.  And a generous portion too.

You have to get your own sauces from the dispensers, if you want more than just ketchup for your to go orders.  But the person giving me the bag informed me of that, so no problem.  And that way I could take extra, to make sure I didn't run out - and some for later.  We took some Andouille (I think) sauce, which was basically a spicy mayo with a sneaky heat - it was really good for dipping the fries; and took some of their "secret sauce", which was a sweetish, syrup thick sauce - hard for me to define it, but it made a good chicken dip.

So a decent experience overall.  Pretty good food, takes a bit of time but you want it fresh and hot, still not sure if it's 2x as good as fast food for 2x the price.
name: Chicken Out
categories: Sandwiches, Restaurants

text:
I've heard nothing but good things about DD Mau in Maryland Heights so of course I had to try it once they opened in my area! I've been here twice in one week because it's so delicious, and my boyfriend got hooked too. 

The chicken vermicelli bowl with peanut sauce was super filling and full of flavor. Ask for extra sauce if you like yours super saucy!

They have fried vegetarian rolls and really tasty, fresh chicken spring rolls that go well with the chili sauce or peanut sauce. 

I've had lots of fried rices and their veggie fried rice (add egg!) is the best there is!

Super friendly staff and the owner is very hospitable. I'm happy we have delicious Vietnamese in the area-- go support local!
name: DD Mau Vietnamese Eatery

text: I mean I had no idea how great this place was going to be until I went on a whim because I was craving fresh and Vietnamese. Coming from Houston there is no shortage of tasty and high quality Vietnamese food because of the strong Vietnamese population the area. The fried rice was on point here. The flavor was just like my favorite place in Houston The Rice Box. The spring rolls and sauce were perfect. Crab Rangoon was tasty. Vegan cheese rolls were a big wow. Lychee limeade made me so happy too. I can't wait to go back.

text:
The new Chicken Out has arrived in Kirkwood/Warson area in the old Shop n Save spot on Manchester, east of Manchester and west of Woodlawn on north side of street. Weird little
Shopping center with poor signage. Worth finding though. Better and more accessible than the Loop location. Same great food. The fries are slightly more addictive than crack. Delicious. I had the Cheep n Cheese with bacon and my wife had the Chicken Out. She was underwhelmed by the chicken but I thought it was consistent and delicious. Very friendly staff. Clean bathrooms. Quick service for fast casual.
name: Chicken Out
categories: Sandwiches, Restaurants

text:
This location is newish to Webster and brings a solid new entry into the restaurant scene that's developing in the WG.  

We've been here and had take out and every time the food has been in point, hot and fresh, flavorful and as best as I can tell authentic.  

We typically order the bowls with steak or shrimp and the sweet chili sauce. For sides we go with the crab Rangoon and shrimp spring rolls.  

If your looking for alternatives to the normal heavy same old same DD is a good choice.  You'll do well to get here early or close to 7:30 which is just before closing time.  

Stop by check it out, your pallet will be pleased.
name: DD Mau Vietnamese Eatery

Absolutely delicious, fresh, and appeals to both my vegetarian taste buds and my husband's meat eating taste buds. I got the vermicelli bowl with tofu. The tofu was SO GOOD. Maybe the best in STL. The sauces - amazing! I got the Vietnamese vinaigrette and the peanut and they were both so good. They followed my special requests perfectly. Everyone in my party loved theirs and it was fast. The Thai ice tea was very good! The only thing I didn't like was the Lychee limeade. I told my husband that I'll be here at least once a week for sure.. if not more.. for a healthy, filling and fast meal.

text:
Dinner for 3

Ordered 2 chicken vermicelli bowls for my wife and me, vegan beef sliders for my daughter, and a couple orders of vegan cheese sticks. 

Turns out they misunderstood (maybe due to speaking through mask) and only placed order for 1 vermicelli bowl. Food seemed to come faster than the 20-25 minutes they told us. Seemed like plenty of food for us even without the extra bowl. 

Daughter didn't care for the sliders (kind of like mini Vietnamese soft tacos), so I finished them off. The sliders were OK, but I don't think we'll order them again. Wife and I both enjoyed the chicken vermicelli bowl, and I think we all enjoyed the vegan cheese sticks. We plan to add this restaurant to our rotation.

text:
This is a great fast-casual addition to Old Webster. They have made some cool updates to the very open space. 

We started with the fresh shrimp spring rolls which were unlike any I've had. The shrimp portion was generous and cooked to perfection and peanut sauce was delicious with them.

I ordered the combo Vermicelli bowl and chose the traditional Vietnamese Vinaigrette. The sauce was very flavorful-both sweet and tart with a nice hint of Umami from the fish sauce. The veggies were fresh and crisp.

My husband ordered combo fried rice which was very flavorful and full of meat and shrimp. My only comment is that the style of fried rice did not have any vegetables. I think this is more than fine for my husband but I prefer to have a little bit in my fried rice.

The service was friendly and reasonably fast given they had a very steady stream of customers.
name: DD Mau Vietnamese Eatery

Alright, this is hard. 

Food was 5 stars. The pizza in particular was terrific. All of the other dishes ordered by our group of 8 came exactly correct and exactly fine tasting. Our server was a very aware of our needs and did a great job keeping things straight. The owner came by and did all those nice things.

Now the hard part:
This place has zero, and I mean zero atmosphere. My garage is more conducive to dining out than this place. I know the goal is Food-Service-Fair Pricing. This is achieved. But dang, dress the place up a tad otherwise this will be a carry out and catering only type of place.

text: At the corner of the building sits DD Mau. It's full of windows and the cutest wallpaper covers every wall. Through the door, you walk up to the counter to see the menu on the wall above the register. After placing our order with ease, I took the order number and found a table. Cute round wooden tables are along then windows while the my also offer a few booths as well. I ordered shrimp spring rolls and chicken pho while my parents got combo fried rice. The spring rolls came out quickly followed by the main dishes. My pho was so delicious. Added hoisin and sriracha to it and made it even better! Parents enjoyed the fried rice as well. Glad we came while I was in town for the holidays!

text:
I was really excited to try DD Mau! I had it on my list for awhile and the night was finally here. We ordered online and did pick up, which was a super easy process. 

We ordered the Vermicelli Bowl with vegetables, Pho, and shrimp spring rolls to share. The Vermicelli Bowl didn't have too much flavor, so the sauce I got (peanut) was very needed. At first my fiance was disappointed by the Pho as the additions he added were pinches and didn't seem worth the extra cost, but once he assembled it all he said it had pretty good flavor. The shrimp spring rolls were the best part, but they were just ok. We got spicy peanut sauce with them and it tasted just like the peanut sauce for the bowl - not spicy at all. 

I'm glad we tried it out and maybe we will return again, but not at the top of my list.
name: DD Mau Vietnamese Eatery

text: Got the pulled pork, brisket, burnt ends and mac and cheese. Also ordered the Collard Greens and Pinto Beans, but they were missing from our order, so not sure.  The mac and cheese was creamy and had the Red Hot Riplets seasoning. The burned ends were also very good.  The pulled pork was dry and didn't really have much of a bark or rub flavor.  The brisket was undercooked and was dry and rubbery. I asked for slices from both flat(lean) and point(fatty) to get a good sample, but the order just had slices from the flat.   I love Navin R. Johnson and I love BBQ so I was excited to see this place open.   Can't really recommend the brisket or pork, hoping it gets better.
name: Navinâs BBQ

We tried the Jerk sandwich (loved the slaw on the sandwich), the Hot Brown, the pulled chicken dinner, mac & cheese, collard greens, mashed potato salad and the sweet heat slaw. text: Another strong operation by the Sugarfire/HiPointe team. Not sure what people are expecting when they say the prices are high...this is not a chain fast food restaurant. It's a local quick-service restaurant with sandwiches in the $7.50-8.50 range. Prices were completely in line for the product and experience, service was fast and friendly when dining in for lunch on Sunday. We waited about 10 mins for our food, and it was piping hot, crispy and fresh. Good variety of housemate sauces. Thin crinkle-cut fries as well as the fried chicken sandwiches and strips are excellent! Everything is clean, decor is bright and cute, so happy they came out to suburbia.
name: Chicken Out
categories: Sandwiches, Restaurants

text: I seen this place passing by and I wanted to try it out! It's pricey! The chicken sandwich alone is $8+ and then to add a meal almost $5. We got the buff daddy, the chicken out, 2 drinks, a Mac n cheese and a fries. The Mac n cheese was watery and tasted so off, no flavor at all. He said it was the last mac n cheese of the night, not knowing it would be gross. I asked for crispy fries, they weren't crispy at all. The chicken was so dry and hard to chew. Maybe it was old? Maybe reheated? Not sure! The flavor of the buff daddy was good with the slaw which I usually don't care for slaw but it goes good with the chicken sandwich. For the price I'd expect the food to be better and hot! For a family of 4 it would be close to $60 if not more. We left hungry after our meals, not enough food for your money. I honestly think Popeyes chicken sandwich tasted better!!!
name: Chicken Out
categories: Sandwiches, Restaurants

text: It's always nice to feel welcomed! I was so excited to see Krueger's reopen in May. Even better is their new menu which will delight every one regardless of food preference. The pretzel bite appetizer is a bite of heaven. Since May, this neighborhood bar has been destination number one for my friends and I. Did I mention the great mixologists behind the bar? They will bring a smile to your face with cocktails that make the days challenge a distant memory.
name: Krueger's Bar

text:
I've been here 3 times since they opened, and I am sure they are going to be successful in this location. The food is really good and the space is pretty with lots of windows. I have been on a mission to find the best vegetarian Banh Mi in STL, and this place delivers. Only Banh Mi So on South Grand competes, and it isn't clear who wins.

They are going through some opening pains at the moment, though. I think they aren't set up in the kitchen for the current popularity. Be prepared to wait if you show up during regular lunch or dinner hours; my average wait time for the three visits is over 30 minutes, including one time that I ordered ahead for carry-out. If they get this worked out, then the sky is the limit.
name: DD Mau Vietnamese Eatery

text: I  went there for lunch today.  I know this location just opened, so I might give it another chance. The chicken was dry , the bun was nothing special, and the cheddar sauce was bland.  The fries were lukewarm, but good. The thing that got me was the size of the drink, a can of soda would  not fit in it.  For almost  $15.00, I expect  a soda to last  throughout the meal, and  a  sandwich with some flavor. The chicken place down the street is half the price , the food is good, and the size of the drinks are normal.  I hope things get better.

categories: Sandwiches, Restaurants

text: Been there a few times....always fast fresh chicken with a nice choice of sides and dipping sauces.

text:
Amazing! So glad this location opened up! 

I usually get the rare steak or combo pho. The broth is always tasty! My husband usually goes for the steak rice bowl. Everything is so filling with big proportions! That goes for the fried rice too. I can't stop taking another bite. It's addicting. 

For appetizers, I always do the crispy egg rolls with the vinaigrette sauce. I also love the shrimp spring rolls. It's seasoned well, and all the ingredients are so fresh! Try it with the peanut sauce - it's a game changer. 

I've tried several of their drinks over the years. The classic iced coffee is good! I liked the Marsala chai tea and recently enjoyed a new lychee drink too!

One of my favorite things about this restaurant is that they have their staple items but they always seem to have new menu items too! I'm on the email chain and I've seen coconut shrimp, vegan cheese rolls, desserts.. I like that this place can get adventurous and offer a wide range of options for customers. For any family, it seems you'll find something for everyone!

*update: my brother in law is vegan and he raves about their tasty vegan options! What a win!!
name: DD Mau Vietnamese Eatery

text: Had been looking forward to this restaurant opening, but was severely disappointed with my visit. First waited 5 minutes for my turn to place my order at the drive through.  When I was able to pull up to the speaker I was asked to hold.  After 3 minutes I started saying "Hello" but never got a response.  After 4 more minutes the person behind me asked if I could pull through so they could leave.  As I pulled up to the pickup window I honked several times but no one came.  I parked and went inside.  Explained the drive thru situation and no one apologized,  but took my order.  I ordered the spicy sandwich.  When I got home the chicken patty was 2/3 the size of the bun.  Very small for a $7.50 sandwich.  When I started to eat it I realized they gave me a regular sandwich and not the spicy sandwich.  So no more and back to driving much further to Chick-Fil-A.
name: Chicken Out
categories: Sandwiches, Restaurants

text: I used the online ordering and the food was ready to go when I walked in the restaurant.   I ordered the combo burnt ends with Mac and cheese and my wife got pulled pork the potato salad and the collard greens.   The food contained spice with a capsaicin component.   My wife thought the collard greens were too spicy.  I thought so as well.   The pulled pork was acceptable.  I thought the burnt ends were great.   The pork belly burnt ends are like melt in your mouth bacon.  The brisket burnt end were similar to eating rib meat.   The Mac and cheese was creamy with an excellent cheese flavor.   I tried the potato salad, wasn't for me, but everyone has their own tastes.   I definitely plan to order again.

text:
I read the local restaurant critic's review of DD Mau's new location, where he raved about it, and decided I needed to try the place out.  Pleased to say that I agree with his enthusiasm.  This is a fast casual set up, and the menu board is set up pretty well to explain the options.  However, there are quite a few choices, so you might want to hang back and figure it out before stepping up to place your order.  When we arrived at about 6 pm on a Friday, it was pretty busy,  especially with people standing to take to go orders.  There were still a couple of 4 place tables open (along with a number of 2 place tables), so we snagged one.  But all the people standing around can make it difficult to get to a table.  Regardless, the food came out pretty quickly considering the number of orders that were before us - only 5-10 minutes and probably a dozen+ orders.

All of our food was really good.  My shrimp spring rolls were loaded with tender yet snappy and well seasoned large shrimp, along with fresh veggies.  Steak bao sliders were excellent, with savory shredded steak filling.  I am a sucker for good steamed bao buns.  There were warm, moist and soft without any gumminess.  I also got a combo banh mi, since I'm a hungry fool.    It had a nice variety of filling (shrimp, steak, etc), topped with a generous amount of fresh shredded veggies on a crunchy baguette with warm mayo.  A good sandwich, which it should be since they aren't too difficult to do and I usually get good ones from the various joints.

The wife and daughter raved over their rice bowls.  Since I didn't eat the bowls, I'll just have to go on their word.  The daughter's had pork, and the wife's had crispy tofu.  I did try a piece of the tofu, and it is notable.  A light breading on the extra firm fried tofu was something notable - I think even tofu non-eaters would enjoy it.  I could eat a serving of that by itself.
name: DD Mau Vietnamese Eatery

text:
Not bad.   Long long line in drive thru.  Should have went inside but super courteous.   Friendly service, hot food and all the essentials packed in the bag without having to ask. 

My daughter ordered the spicy hot.  Sooooo good.  Thick, juicy fried piece of chicken.  Crispy coating just perfect.  Sauce was perfection.   Nice presentation.  

I ordered the fit chic.  Not bad and yes I would order again.  They offer grilled or fried.  I believe fried defeats the fit part of the description but lots not get too technical.  The avocado sauce was tasty.  It was a tad dry but still worth the purchase.   After trying the spicy hot it was challenging to stay focused on mine. 

2 sandwiches = $17+.
name: Chicken Out

text: I was excited to go here but unfortunately, since I'm on the younger side of their customers, I was ripped off. I paid for a drink with my card, mind you there was about ten people in the bar, and I never received it. When I asked for my drink they made it and then asked for payment, I told them I had already paid and they said it didn't go through. Even though the charge came up on my account. Annoyingly I gave the man a $20 bill and then he tried to give me a one dollar bill back. When I called him out he tried to argue with me but I was not having it. Thankfully he gave me my change back and although it may have been an honest mistake I ended up paying ten dollars for one drink. I know just turning 21 that we aren't your favorite people to please, but we are bringing in a majority of your business and it would be nice to be respected !
name: Krueger's Bar

text:
Friendly staff, excellent fast food chicken sandwich.

If you are in the mood for a chicken sandwich and have fast casual expectations this is your spot.  Chicken Out is for those looking for an upgrade on your typical chicken sandwich.  The chicken sandwich marketing war is a bit absurd so I will spare you the theatrics and simply say that their sandwiches are worth the couple extra bucks.

The pandemic should update your expectations from fast food joints and dining out in general.  I think old expectations are driving a lot of the other reviews I have read.  If ~14$ per meal (at the time of writing this review) and a 5-10 minute wait are dealbreakers for you avoid Chicken Out, otherwise enjoy a better fast food chicken joint.
name: Chicken Out
categories: Sandwiches, Restaurants

text: If you like a chik-fil-a chicken sandwich once a while, you will most definitely enjoy the Chicken Out chicken sandwich. This is my new favorite chicken restaurant. The prices are a little high considering it's +$4 for a small drink and fries.
name: Chicken Out
categories: Sandwiches, Restaurants

text:
Update: we ordered 2 vermicelli bowls and spring rolls tonight. The food tasted fresh and good, but I'm knocking 1 star off because they screwed up our order again -- this time, instead of the peanut sauce we ordered, my wife's bowl came with something else, that I'm guessing must be "DD dressing". Also the spring rolls were stuck together badly enough that the skins tore open when I tried to separate them.

I've eaten at many Vietnamese restaurants over decades, and don't recall seeing these problems before. DD Mau has good food, and a lot of promise, but needs some more attention to the little details.

text:
I ordered the smoked brisket sandwich, which was okay, but I didn't make a yummy noise when I bit into it. The bread was dry and the meat was underseasoned. For sides I had the mashed potato salad (which was mustard based), and slaw. The slaw was bitter but I didn't hate it. I also got a bottle of cola, which was flat. I went to immediately throw it away in the trash in their dining room. They have one of those trash cans like in fast food dining rooms. When I opened the flap to toss the soda, it was so full I could hardly fit the bottle in there and a wave of gnats flew out at me. The guy at the counter gave me my order: the brisket sandwich, potato salad, and slaw, and told me it was a different sandwich at first, which caused some confusion. Then he gave me my bag, called me sweetie, and walked away. He had only put one of my sides in there. 
So it was a bunch of these little things that added up to one crummy experience.
-Boring sando
-Flat soda
-Disgusting trash can
- "Sweetie"
-Incomplete order (and he called it out wrong to me)

I don't need your boring sando sir. 
And I ain't your sweetie, sweetie.
name: Navinâs BBQ

categories: Restaurants, Vietnamese

text:
Finally tried this place out! I have been by a couple of times but they were closed, unfortunately.  On Friday, I placed and order online for a pickup.  My pickup time was about 13 minutes from placing my order which was super quick.

I ordered some spring rolls with pork and added shrimp for a starter, a bowl of pho with rare beef, and a vermicelli bowl with steak pieces and an extra egg added to the bowl.  During pickup, I went on the line because there wasn't a sign directing where people with online order pick-ups  should go. I got to the counter and the very friendly worker at the counter handed me my order.  They were still hot and fresh when I arrived (5 minutes or so drive).

While I did not have the pho, it did look quite appetizing and smelled great.  My vermicelli bowl was okay.  The veggies were fresh and the protein of choice was quite flavorful but the noodles themselves were slightly undercooked just by a little bit.  I opted for the DD sauce and unfortunately, I find that I'm not a fan.  It kind of just made me think of a sweeter mayonnaise. Perhaps a different sauce would bring out better flavors.  I would definitely like to try something else more savory and less creamy/mayonnaise-like.  The Vietnamese egg roll that came with my vermicelli bowl was okay, could have been slightly more flavorful and the egg was slightly too underdone for my liking -- uncooked egg whites surrounding the yolk.  There was no way to choose cooking preferences either. I wonder if I had dined inside if they would have had the option to cook it a little longer?

Based on my experience, I would go with a 3 but I'd like to come back and give them another try as they do have a lot of different options.  Next time maybe I'll get the pho.
name: DD Mau Vietnamese Eatery

text:
I dunno, this place is ok. If we lived in a town with no, or not very good Vietnamese food, I could see DD Mau warranting more than 3 stars.
As it stands their offerings are on the whole really bland, in stark comparison to their Vietnamese food competitors. Seriously, St. Louis has quality Vietnamese food, and most of it is really approachable to your standard mid western palate. I don't see any reason to go light on the fish sauce, in their "vinaigrette" for example. Probably the best and most unique thing here, are the boa sliders and the "tacos." I'm hard pressed to think of another restaurant in town that offers something like this.
name: DD Mau Vietnamese Eatery

Ended up ordering the shrimp vermicelli bowl with the spicy dd sauce and a Thai idea tea.  Food came out pretty quick and was yummy and flavorful. text:
A well-deserved Five Star Bump goes to DD Mau!

A couple of nights ago, we decided to come in and give this place a second try.  We both ordered pho; one with rare beef and the other with meatballs.  I got the rare beef this time and my husband, the meatballs.  We also shared an order of pork bao with hoisin sauce.  

We were seated and in less than 5 minutes, our food came out with the soup piping hot and the ingredients, fresh-tasting!  They gave us very generous portions of pho and they came with individually plated bean sprouts, mint sprig, a few slices of jalapenos still with seeds on, and a slice of lime.  I don't care for lime much in my pho but I took advantage of the plentiful veggies.  By the end of our meal, I couldn't even finish my food because the bowl was filled with so much pho-ntastic noodles and broth!

Did I mention how delicious their bao was?! Oh my... I will most likely return soon just to get an order or 2 of their bao to snack on.  The bun were soft and perfect, the pork and veggie filling were delicious and added a bit of crunch, and the hoisin sauce brought everything together in one delicious package.

I can't say this enough but I can't wait to come back soon and order more of their pho and bao.  I'm so glad this place exists and is so much closer than any other pho places.  They have truly made a fan out of me!
name: DD Mau Vietnamese Eatery

text:
It's a little corner bar on Forsyth between downtown Clayton and Washington University.  This is still a smoking establishment.

They have a number of specials - both daily specials which can be viewed on their website and other specials.  Today they had hot tomales, chili, and beef brisket.  But I went with what I knew and what the previous two reviewers mentioned as well - the burger.

I had the bison burger ($7.50) with soft cheddar (add 75c).  If you get the bison and they ask how you want it cooked, I would recommend medium.  You don't want bison overcooked.  The soft cheddar topping was tasty, but man, does it melt/slide right off your burger.  It takes a bit of maneuvering to keep your sandwich together.  (Using my best memory on the prices)

You get a choice of side, and I had the fries.  They were surprisingly very good for "bar and grill" fries.  I made a mixture of mayo and ketchup to dip them in.

One friend got the brisket and liked it.  Another friend got the reuben and was surprised how tasty the corned beef was, so that really stood out.

Good service, good food.  My burger, fries, and soda ($2) cost me about $12 after tax, not counting tip.
name: Krueger's Bar
