text: Tried Chicken Out today! I had the chicken out crispy, husband had the spicy chicken out. We sat outside by the large fiberglass chicken, there is a drive thru you come in from Manchester and drive around the front to get to the back where the menu and speaker are then exit on side of building (see pic) Definitely rivals Chick -fil -a although different. The potato buns are fresh and good, the pickles are standard. Crinkle cut fries had some spices they were good. We liked the onion rings especially for a fast casual they get high marks. It says "sometimes" they have shakes but they did not today. You can see them making the food fresh. The drinks are in a smaller I think 16 oz so be prepared for that. In addition to the price of the sand it's $4.50 to make it a meal. You are at 13$ for a meal. I downloaded app and when I tried to use the promo for signing up and the one for downloading app both were rejected by the app when I clicked redeem "not redeemable at this location" . It definitely costs more than Chick-fil- a , but it's not necessarily better. Location is close to home and very happy to have Chicken Out in our 'hood!
name: Chicken Out
categories: Sandwiches, Restaurants

text:
I was a little skeptical when I heard that St. Louis finally had a good spot for barbecue, but during a recent drive through the Midwest I decided to take a chance and check out Navin's and I'm REALLY glad I did.

We decided to order a little bit of everything and found the entire menu to be delicious, but I've gotta give some extra credit points to the burnt ends (both the brisket and pork belly) and the smoked chicken wings (which I never usually order but these ones were truly something special).

Don't sleep on this place -- check out Navin's ASAP!
name: Navinâs BBQ

text:
Average at best.

My first experience with DD Mau was exceptional... Very high-quality and terrific portions at their other location. 

This location - food had reasonable flavor but was light on the filling for the Banh Mi sandwich. 

$3.35 for a soda... That should give you a perspective on their pricing strategy... Maybe that's also why the sandwich was so skimpy. The Pho was "just OK" and nothing special.

Front counter server was terrific! 

General overall service was just OK.

A little pricey, average food and a really nice location... With average service


When I go back? Probably not
name: DD Mau Vietnamese Eatery

text:
Crazy expensive. Sandwich $7.50 however making it a combo (crinkle fries + small soda) was an additional $4.50.  
Sandwich was good, but not great. Far better sandwiches at far better prices. Go elsewhere.
name: Chicken Out
categories: Sandwiches, Restaurants

text:
I'm curious as to how the fees add up because my total in the drive through was $28.xx (was not given a receipt so not 100% sure what the exact total was) but my order was only $23.50 before tax. So unless Kirkwood has 20% sales tax (they don't) there is something going on in the fine print of how you are charging customers. I wanted to see what the total would be if I ordered online (picture attached) and there is a "service tip" ... to me this implies it goes to your workers. Is that correct? But then you ask people to tip on a drive through...It's just all a bit confusing to me. 

Food was excellent. Ordered the spicy chicken out and added ghost pepper. Highly recommend! 

I received the wrong order, though, and had to park and go into the restaurant. (Should have checked when I was still in line!)

I'll probably go back since the food was good, just would appreciate more transparency in how you charge customers.
name: Chicken Out
categories: Sandwiches, Restaurants

text:
Tried the Pho today with "rare" beef steak today and it was Fantastic.   Broth was a light brown color and had great flavor and mouth feel.  Lots of noodles with bean sprouts on the side and house made condiments to spice it up with.  The beef was sliced thin and when served in that hot broth there is no hint of "rare" but it was tender and added nicely to the dish.   It was a very nice sized portion as well, so you do get plenty of food pho the money 

If you live in the area and enjoy Asian flavors please go support this business!  The food is great!
name: DD Mau Vietnamese Eatery

text: This was our first visit and our last. We ordered a two meat combo plate with brisket and burnt ends. The brisket was dry and under smoked, and the burnt ends or fatty and not pleasant to eat. The quantity of the meat for $18 was quite small compared to salt and smoke and sugar fire. And the sides or just as unimpressive. You could do a lot better for your barbecue dollar at salt and smoke and enjoy a better product for sure.

text: Attended here for a wedding dinner. Had heard good reviews of this restaurant, so we were excited. Luckily, the hype was not overrated. We were pleasantly surprised by the high quality of Chinese food offered. We had a 12 course meal, with the most memorable dishes being the Peking duck, the shao long bao, the steamed fish, the crispy beef, and the "potted plant" dessert. Having eaten Chinese food all over the east coast, this food was definitely on par, and in some instances, even better. By far be best Chinese food available in STL. We will def be back!
name: Private Kitchen

text:
I cannot believe it took me as long as it did to dine here. Within the first taste of the soup dumplings I was already planning my next trip back. Also debating if the dumplings would survive a trip home where I could gorge myself in the luxury of stretchy pants. My dining companion doubted my commitment. 

Private Kitchen is a dining experience. One you must work for and rightfully so. You must make a reservation and order at the time of your reservation. Texting is best- 314-445-4605, not the business phone but the personal cell phone of the chef and his wife who will respond to you. The Menu is on Facebook and you can inquire about specials. 

The location is an unassuming business district and inside decor is minimal. Tables are set and furnished according to the reservations for the night. Simple and clean. The focus is on the cuisine. 

Then out comes your selections. For us it was the soup dumplings, Yangzhou lion head, Chinese broccoli, house beef in chef's private sauce, and the braised shrimp. Everything was piping hot and perfectly prepared. The soup dumplings stole the show and now a week after our dining experience are still all I think about. ORDER THE SOUP DUMPLINGS. The Yangzhou lion head is intricate and simple at the same time. The house beef and the Chinese broccoli are not to be missed and we managed to clean our plates despite being more than full. 

Cannot wait to come back and try out more of the menu. No doubt it will be incredible.
name: Private Kitchen

text: Definitely the best authentic Chinese restaurant in St. Louis. You have to make a reservation in advance, though. Every time I went there I ordered different dishes but every time I was satisfied. The dished are small because they only keep the best part of the vegetables/meat to serve. An interesting story is that I once treated a couple to dinner there and they came after they had a dinner party at another Chinese restaurant and they told me they were quite full when they showed up. But when the dishes were served, they ate no less than me and another friend because the foods were just so good.
name: Private Kitchen

text: Super disappointed in Bobby's Place. My friends and I have been going here for YEARS. So I thought it would be the perfect place to throw a party for a friend moving back to STL. I was told I had a reserved spot, but when we got there, nothing had been reserved and we had to sit outside. I was even more disappointed that nothing was done to rectify the situation and no apology was made. Go to bobbys for a drink but don't waste your time trying to host a party there or reserve a spot. Overall, I don't think any of us will be back.

text: This was my first time to Stl Soup Dumplings which seems to be part of the Private Kitchen restaurant.  The menu is quit simple: soup dumplings, pork, beef, shrimp, pork and crab, and I think that's it.  You go to the counter to order and in a few short minutes the little steamer baskets arrived, neatly stacked. Before the dumplings arrived they brought us little bowls of chicken broth, simple but tasty. The dumplings were hot and moist. I can't say which one was best because they were all fantastic.   The server, who was the only employee I saw, was very friendly also. On the table they have a tray with soy sauce, hot chili paste, and I think vinegar. The people with me raved about the chili paste. It was too hot for me. The only suggestion I have is some dipping sauces. Dipping sauces may not be entirely authentic, but I like them. Overall, I will be back! I highly recommend!
name: Private Kitchen

text:
Let me be pretty clear about why I'm giving this place five stars: The food is absolutely delicious, so fresh, and truly authentic. The service is very subpar. I brought my parents here after coming with a group of friends. If you didn't know, you reserve a table (I would recommend by texting the number they provide) and order the food ahead of time. The ingredients are bought day of (I'm pretty sure) and just enough for the five tables in the restaurant. Everything is prepped as you're walking in (I would not be late). My parents were wowed by the quality of the peking duck and the skill it takes to cut it, the quality of the beef used, and the freshness of the pea tips. The taste is so delicious and leaves you wanting to eat so so much more. 

We were a group of four and ordered (2) soup dumplings, a Peking duck, spicy beef, mushroom soup, pea tips with chicken broth, dried bean curd mixed with ma lan, house beef, and spicy beef. It was a LOT of food with enough leftovers for a full lunch the next day. 

As for the service, it's best to say what my mom said: "it's non-existent." Basically, the wife (the husband cooks in the back) just brings you whatever food has been prepared for you, not really looking out for the order of the guests. She was perfectly nice and had some conversation with us but we just wanted our food. We arrived a little bit before a full group arrived and we received three dishes before we were basically put on hold until the large group received close to 6 different dishes (took around 30 minutes between our 3rd and 4th dish. Keeping in mind that we only had 2 hours to eat) We were really hungry (and the food was so good) but there wasn't any care taken to balance out serving every guest. I also noticed that it took forever for them to serve the other smaller tables around us as well. I'm still giving this place five stars because the food is just that good.
name: Private Kitchen

text: Thoroughly enjoyable dinner.  Great timing as to the delivery of all the dishes we ordered.  We had a table of 8 and it worked perfectly with the lazy susan for a family style dinner.  Presentation on the spicy lobster dish was very unique with the carved dragon head and tail out of carrots.  The spicy beef and kung pao chicken was delicious.  Very friendly hosts.  Requires some planning ahead since it is reservation only and you must pre-order your meal.

text: So...here's the thing....had great hopes for this neighborhood spot. Not new, but new ownership... sadly disappointed!  Been three times.. #1 - newly opened, owner made pretense of introducing himself ... yada,yada....Time #2- super busy, took awhile for waitress to take order, apologizes...Time #3...tonight.rainy, fairly empty..get the picture?  My husband and I came in, took a seat...owner, Doug, never looked up from his perch at the end of the bar....10 minutes or so after we sat down, another couple came in. Doug, finally looked up-and surprise- went to couple who came in AFTER us! Took their drink order, came back and took their food order...then proceeded to total other patron's bar bills, not once looking in our direction...All these patrons lacking melanin in their skin...FINALLY...enough is enough...we got up and left, first calling out Doug for his obvious oversight, who claimed he did.not see us, which of course is the inherent problem ...WE WILL NEVER BE BACK and people of color...BE WARNED...go elsewhere or you will risk being blatantly and obviously ignored! Spend your green elsewhere as we did!!!
name: Thurman's in Shaw

text: We went there within the past two weeks. Nice,quiet atmosphere. Good jazz. Honestly,the food was mediocre. The extremely small street Taco's might have had a tablespoon and a half of meat and,virtually,nothing else. It would have helped to have some diced tomatoes,cilantro,cheese, & maybe a teaspoon more of meat. Sauces came in very small containers that might have held a tablespoon and half of product. Taco's were 3 something a piece. Very over priced. Tasty but not much to them. All of the Mex food needs to be elevated to equal the price. Nothing special otherwise and over priced. Very average. Good staff. Friendly. Service could be better even with 4 people in the whole place.
name: Thurman's in Shaw

text:
Everything about this place is perfect. The food is outstanding, ambiance is wonderful, and service is impeccable. The pork soup dumplings, three ingredient vegetables, and Peking duck were the highlights of the evening. It is clear they take a lot of pride in their food; everything is meticulously prepared.

This is easily the best Chinese food in St. Louis and an extremely unique and impressive restaurant. I highly recommend Private Kitchen when you have people visiting from out of town, want to celebrate a special occasion, or just want outstanding Chinese food because the prices are very reasonable.
name: Private Kitchen

text: People in Shaw love their neighborhood establishments and no disrespect to them. But if you're not buddy-buddy with the clientele going to Thurman's is kind of like going to the dog park across the street: it's a fine experience, but it's not meant for you. I've been there three times over the course of the year and live right down the street, but no one who works there has ever been particularly friendly to me or my partner. Nor is it the sort of place where you can meet new people, especially if you're not of the same race and age group. The beer selection is small, the drinks are OK, and the food is a little expensive for the quality (good wings though). If you're not meeting a Thurman's regular I suggest checking out any of the other bars in the neighborhood.
name: Thurman's in Shaw

text:
After trying several times, we were finally able to get a reservation for our group of 7 on a Sunday night! We learned that that the best way to make a reservation was to use a chat app, otherwise calling the restaurant is hit or miss.
There were only 2 other groups at our dinner time, another table of 8 and a group of 4. The 3 total tables filled the restaurant and kept Mrs Yang, our hostess and wife of the chef busy the rest of the evening! They only offered 2 wines, but we brought our own for a $10 corkage fee.

Our first dish was the famous Xiao Long Bao, as others described. It's a small, bite-sized dumpling, filled with tender, savory ground pork, bathed in a rich stock, clothed in a soft wrap and steamed in a bamboo basket. What a first course!
Next came the Peking Duck. Crisp skin, succulent meat, well seasoned. It was served with finely juilienned fresh cucumber and scallions (great knife skills!) and the traditional sweet hoisin sauce. The rest of the duck was served in a separate platter, which was emptied in 5 minutes!
We also had the steamed fresh groupa fish. Traditional simple chinese style with sesame oil, soy sauce, ginger and scallions. True to our group, I wish I took an "after" picture to show you how well we cleaned off the fish bones! 
We then had the tamarind crab, it was the most delectable crab I've ever had! Coming from Singapore where crab is king (I've had Chili crab, Black Pepper crab, salted egg yolk crab, steamed crab), this tamarind crab is to die for! Delicious mix of umami, sweet and salty, the crab was large and full of meat! Well seasoned, the flavor was full with every bite. 
With the guidance of another friend who's a regular, we ordered another of their specialties, the Lion's Head Meatball (loosely translated). As Mrs Yang explained, this dish requires the most amount of time and effort!. The meat is hand chopped, not machine ground. Seasoned, the made into meatballs the size of baseballs! They are stuffed into chicken and simmered for hours. The meatballs are served with the flavor infused broth and a single head of baby bak choy, all in a beautiful white porcelain bowl with it's own wrought-iron stand.
We also ordered the shrimp fried rice, which was al dente rice and not clumpy. We also had spicy tofu (similar to Ma Po Tofu) which was flavored with fermented beans and chili. The sweet and sour eggplant with green peppers was another hit. We lastly got a mushroom soup, with 3 kinds of mushrooms. It was simple, not oily, a perfect closer to the savory entrees. 

For dessert, we had 2 kinds of dessert, the default is often the "potted plant". It's a really artful serving of white porcelain bowl in a the shape of mini square vase. In it is selected vanilla ice cream that's not too sweet or creamy, on top is a layer of semi-sweet cocoa granules, with a single baby carnation sitting the middle, creating the potted plant appearance. Brilliant, playful. The other dessert we got was the housemade, traditional, fermented sweet rice with tapioca pearls. This was a hit! A perfect, truly final closer to our Shanghainese gastronomic experience!

Our 10 course meal came up to less than $40 per person for a group of 7. Truly a steal for such culinary extravaganza! Each dish had it's own unique flavor. Unlike many places, where one sauce was used for everything and most dishes tasted the same, the food here at Private Kitchen clearly shines through with the Yang's love for the preparation and presentation of meals as a labor of their passion.
name: Private Kitchen

text: A great neighborhood spot. Good beer selection with a lot of local stuff and a really awesome patio. I liked this place a lot when it had solid American style pub food. But recently they changed things up and now serve high quality, inexpensive Mexican street food and I love Thurman's even more. We're here at least once a week when the weather is nice. And the patio is a great place to hang out and drink while your kids run around. I'm usually home before the live music starts, but the jazz is supposed to be great--in fact, the place got written up in the New York Times as a music venue (no joke). Check it out!
name: Thurman's in Shaw

The service was friendly, but you need to be a bit proactive if you would like to order beer or wine. A special place and absolutely worth a visit.

text:
I would agree with the previous review that many of the dishes can be found on other Chinese menus. However what sets Private Kitchen's apart is that they are being made by one man, to order, with a more personal and delicate taste. 

We ordered Peking Duck (need to order in advance). This was delicious! 

The other orders we made upon arrival so we could view the menu. The menu does change according to what is available. 

We also had the black mushrooms with Bok Choy, soup dumplings, and spicy bean curd. 

Overall we were al delighted with the food. It was delicious and beautifully presented. 



They do not currently have a liquor license.
name: Private Kitchen

text:
This is a Shaw favorite! We love the atmosphere and it's a great spot to run into neighbors. The staff is always friendly and we love the specialty drinks. Jazz on Thursdays and special events are fantastic, and Thurman's is also a great place to catch local sports games -- which is what we do sometimes because we only have internet TV. My favorite drink is the Sweet Revenge mule, but everything they've suggested has been great. The food is regular bar good, but that's usually just right on a Thurman's night!

We're glad Thurman's is in Shaw. It's one more reason we love the neighborhood.
name: Thurman's in Shaw

text: The Thurman Grill has new ownership, a new name, and a completely new look. Now Thurman's in Shaw, this great neighborhood bar keeps a nice local beer selection on tap, a fantastic whiskey selection, and they've even added a fryer to the kitchen. The chicken tenders are some of the best I've had and the onion rings are spot on with a nice crunch. Pricing for food is reasonable and the portions large. The new owner keeps up Thurman's  music chops with regular blues, jazz and other music acts. It's also the most impressive sound system I've seen in a neighborhood bar. Simply stated, if you haven't been to Thurman's since their remodel and reopening, I highly recommend checking it out.
name: Thurman's in Shaw

text: This place is awesome. Went with a party of ten, and some of our Chinese friends ordered in advance (you have to do this). You can be as adventurous as you want, but our food was nothing weird to Americans (we weren't real interested in tendons, sea cucumber, etc.). The house special beef is the best stir-fried beef I've ever had, and really, everything is good. The dishes are served beautifully, and there is only one server, who appears to be one of the proprietors. There are about five tables in the restaurant, and it was quite busy when we went. The prices vary--our meal ended up being about $20 a person with very little alcohol. But we didn't have the lobster or some of the other dishes that are probably pretty pricey.
name: Private Kitchen

text: Came here with my sister and brother in law on a recent trip to St Louis. The food was amazing! When I called to set up my reservation, Lawrence, the owner and chef asked me what I wanted to order so that he could buy the ingredients the day of for extra freshness. It was an interesting experience that I'd never had before in the states for a full meal, and added to the anticipation. Also, clever business model! We started with the steamed dumplings which were hot but so flavorful, especially with the vinegar sauce, that it was totally worth the scalding! Then came the peking duck, which came with little rice buns and plum sauce for sandwiches. The skin was so crispy and the meat so juicy that my sister giggled in enjoyment as she ate it. It was that good. That one had to be ordered two days in advance, which was fine, as they require reservations. Then came Chinese broccoli, which looked like broccoli rabe in a sweet sauce, black pepper beef, which was cubed and maybe fried? also in a sweeter sauce and finally shrimp with the heads still on. We were encouraged to eat the shell and it was totally worth it! Added a bit of crunch! The rest of the duck, which wasn't immediately served, was turned into a broth for the end of the meal. No waste! The owner's wife is the only wait staff and it gets a bit crazy when all the tables were full (on a random Monday night!), but she handled it well. Overall an excellent meal, if a little sweet. Would strongly recommend.
name: Private Kitchen

categories: Chinese, Restaurants, Shanghainese, American (Traditional)

text:
We expected to enjoy high quality, home-style Chinese food in unusual environments but the whole experience was just alright. 

Unlike the true "private kitchens" which usually operate out of office buildings or obscure corners of a residential region and have little or no signage, this is another ordinary Chinese restaurant among those on olive Blvd. No specific address to track down, no referee persons needed, all that you have to do is to make a booking and order through a mobile chat application. 

A quick read-through of their menu you will see they do not offer special or season-driven items. Most of the menu items are also available in other Chinese restaurants. Food here are of much higher prices.

We were led to our table by the hostess and a teakettle was ready. Her husband started making the food we pre-ordered once we were seated. They were probably aware that tea is an integral part of the meal, but we all could tell it was a cheap tea by a sniff. 

The food is based on traditional Shanghainese and Northeastern China cooking. We had slow-cooked pork knuckle, steamed chicken, sweet and sour fish (squirrel fish)  and bean curd with crab roe. The presentation was good, and ingredients were fresh. The pork knuckle was well done, collagen rich but a little grease-laden. The sizzling squirrel fish was crispy and coated in homemade sauce. We believed it would be better if perked up with more tartness. The other two were just mediocre. 

One star off for being over-rated and extraneous mystery. One star off for being over-priced.
name: Private Kitchen

text: My first time here after about a year ago when they first open. They expand the grocery store and it's really nice and clean! I used to go to Global Market for my Asian grocery but I think I will go here instead. I'm asian myself and love the food here (China Bistro inside the store). It reminds me of H Mart (Korean Store) in Chicago and Boston. I ordered Young Chow Fried Rice. It's very tasty and delicious! Can't wait to go back to try different food on their menu.

text:
I've been curious about this place for a while so we took an opportunity to go for my husband's birthday, the day before Xmas Eve. It was a strange experience.
I've read all the reviews so I know it's a husband making all the food and the wife running the front of the house.
Thanks to fellow Yelpers, I was able to text our order based on their Facebook photos and since it was a special occasion, we ordered way too much food because it all sounded so good!

We arrived 10 minutes earlier than our reservation at 8pm since we were starving and they managed to seat us immediately.
But then after that, the lady proceeded to ignore us besides refilling our water till 8:30. I'm also 9 months pregnant and starving at this point so maybe I was a little crankier than usual.
My husband and his cousin both speak Chinese fluently and my husband politely asked around 8:15 if we could get served soon. She told him that she can only serve one table at a time, which is perplexing because there were other 2 full tables that she was waiting on already, sooo...???
Then at 8:30 my cousin-in-law told her that we had been waiting nearly 45 minutes and the lady's response was "It has NOT been 45 minutes" and rolled her eyes at her. We told her would leave if we didn't get food in the next five minutes and she looked annoyed but immediately started bringing out the food.

The one saving grace was that the food was so delicious, I'm still thinking about it one week later. Every single dish was beautifully made and so tasty. We were bursting by the end of it but had two days worth of leftovers which totally made it worth it.

We tried:
Peking duck (perfection, and I like that they gave us all the parts)
Spicy lobster (more sweet than spicy, in a good way)
Foie gras and black truffle over steamed egg (last dish served, so heavy and perfect)
3 ingredient vegetable--sunchokes, peppers, and eggplant in a sweetened soy sauce (I would go back just for this dish)
House beef (Crispy fried beef, I'm still dreaming about this one)
Lion Head soup (Shanghai specialty, perfect starter to the meal)
Mushroom soup (If you like mushrooms, this one's for you)
Pork Soup Dumplings (another Shanghai specialty, best I've had out of Shanghai)

We actually also ordered the Drunken crab but they texted me saying they didn't have it because the market didn't have very good crab. I responded with "ok that's fine", Then the day of the dinner, I got another text from them saying "You have enough food, you don't need the crab", to which I simply responded with "ok". Not sure if that text was meant for me but it was weird.

Even stranger, the two tables that had already been eating when we arrived most definitely had crab on their tables!

Our total came to $175 before tax and the food was well worth it. But I can't say I enjoyed the experience. The lady who works the front of the house clearly hates her job. I could excuse some of her bad service if communication was a problem but the fact that we had two people who could speak in her native language and she was still so rude was just odd. Not to mention she was offering wine to the other tables and never did so to us. She seemed to have decided to dislike us from the moment we walked in, and we never figured out why.

I was still going to give this 5 stars but all I'm craving is that house beef and the 3 ingredient vegetables and we tried to order it to go today, and apparently they don't do any take out, which I just don't understand! I would love to bypass the service and eat their delicious food on my own terms at home but I guess I can't have that. 

I'm still glad we tried it and I do recommend it, just be prepared for a unique experience!
It's also too bad that the owners will likely never read these reviews because they could probably really benefit from the feedback.
name: Private Kitchen

text:
If you want authentic Chinese in STL, I'd recommend this place gladly. There were about 6-8 tables total inside and you have to make reservations to get one. You text 314-445-4605 to make a reservation. After the chef responds, you give him your order, so be sure to scan the menu. They make the food especially for you and some dishes take days. The service was a lot better than I expected, she smiled a lot and asked if we liked it every now and then. 

We ordered lamb chops, spicy vegetable sauce and pork dumplings. It was all sooo flavorful. The pork dumplings were brought out first and ohhh boy, They were small but mighty. The gooey but savory dumplings paired well with the rice vinegar dip. They were so tasty we regret not ordering more in advanced. 
 
Next the spicy vegetable sauce came out. It was served with white rice. I loovvveee meat so I was surprised at how much I enjoyed this dish. It had a spicy/tangy sauce over eggplant, potatoes and green peppers (I believe). 

Lastly the lamb chops- the tender, juicy lamb chops. I was disappointed that only four came in one order so I would recommend ordering more food if this is your entree option. The spices used on the meat was perfect and meat practically fell off the bone. 

Overall I would recommend this spot to anyone!

text: 6-12 drunk, body builder golfers and their buddies owned the place. My friend and I were repeatedly bumped into while sitting at the bar. One drunk golfer nearly fell down as he spun around and fell into our chairs uttering "sorry" in a blacked-out, blank face. If our chairs were not there he would still be falling. This did not stop the bartender from serving them shots of Fireball! Mind you this was 7-9pm. They obviously were drinking on the golf course all day. CUT THEM OFF FOR EVERYONE'S SAKE ALREADY!! It was very unpleasant just sitting there as we kept getting encroached on by drunks! The last straw was when one of them started twisting my beer bottle in my bucket - right in front of me at my seat! I asked what he was doing and he said he thought it was his bucket. For God's sake it had been sitting in front of me for an hour and was a 40 ounce bottle. When I raised my voice and asked him to get away people took notice. A bouncer suggested we all separate. I had nowhere to go - I was simply sitting at the bar in my stool next to my friend. Some backed off for a while and then came an MS-13 looking tattooed Mexican. He stood with his back to me about 4 inches from my elbow and allowed me to inhale all of the smoke from his cigarette - that he was not smoking. The golfers started buying him drinks for continuing the aggressive inconsideration towards us. Bartenders began ignoring us and essentially stopped service. DO NOT GO HERE!! It is a closed group, drunks were continued to be served and the management did not protect our right to sit at the bar and mind our own business. Lots of Valley Park hoosiers to boot!

text:
For anyone looking for authentic Chinese food in STL, Private Kitchen and Tai Ke should be on your goto list. I've been told that everything here is cooked in a traditional Shanghainese fashion (aka a lot more similar to NE Chinese style cooking, with lighter flavor profiles.) The husband does all the cooking in the back room, and the wife does the serving. There are a few larger tables seating 6-8 people, and some smaller 2 people tables. The place was pretty full when we arrived, and the first thing I noticed was how quiet it was inside.... Or maybe our group was just too rowdy. This would probably be a great place to have a relaxing family dinner or a business dinner, without having to worry about yelling over music or crowd noise. Service was slow in the beginning while the tables before us were getting served, but quickly picked up, with one dish brought after another. 

Booking: This was apparently a PITA, and required a lot of back and forth texting. You can find the contact number, as well as the menu items, on their Facebook page. You're supposed to place all orders during time of booking, so coordinate ahead with your group. 

I have nothing bad to say about the food, so I'll just list them with personal favs at the very top: 
+ Yangzhou lion head 
- served on a per person basis, but could easily be split with others, as the meat is very tender and easy to break off
- pork meatballs will never be the same again after you've had this
- comes with yummy broth that's great to drink up or pour over your rice 

+ soup dumpling with crab roe ("xiao long bao")
- just as good as the original pork version
- ample soup inside the bun (don't bite directly into the center or else the hot soup will splash everywhere)

+ slow cooked pork knuckles
- meat is literally falling off the bone (it's like the Chinese version of Texas bbq :D)
- don't forget to eat the flavor infused skin

+ Peking duck
- not as meaty as the ones I'm used to in Beijing, but just as delicious 
- perfectly crispy skin with tender juicy meat on the inside
- the steamed buns for stuffing are equally heavenly (too bad they're limited, as I could've easily gone for eating just the buns by themselves... They were THAT good)

+ baby pork rib in plum sauce: I still can't get over the bonsai tree garnish, comes with some pieces of plum for good measure (be careful that you don't bite into the plum pit)

+ steamed chicken with green onion: light / mild ("dan") flavor profile with just the right amount of seasoning and none of the overwhelming starchy sauce that Americanized Chinese places add (if you're not used to authentic Chinese food, this dish may not be for you) 

+ steamed whole live fish: also light flavor profile

More importantly, the chopsticks are labeled 'Private Chicken' (someone uploaded a pic of this already.) I still can't get over it.

UPDATE: After coming here a few more times, I've realized that some dishes are just a miss for me. I still maintain that if you want Peking duck, this is probably the best place in Saint Louis to go to. Also, this is a great place for formal gatherings and to impress your co-workers with. However, I personally prefer Tai Ke and Chef Ma's for Chinese food, especially with the added convenience.
name: Private Kitchen

text:
I have been to Thurman's on Friday nights when they have free jazz and it is great. I am someone who goes to see live jazz music regularly, and trust me when I say the Kendrick Smith trio that plays there every Friday is top notch. Also, there is no cover, so it does not get any better than that. 

I've only had bottled beer here and taken a sip of the margarita. The margarita was good! They also have decent drink specials which I have taken advantage of. There is not a huge selection of beer on-tap,  just FYI.

The bar itself is located on a street corner in the middle of the neighborhood. That neighborhood-aspect makes the bar feel very cozy. I can't wait to go here in the winter! They also have a nice patio out front you can sit on with stringed lights. The reason I knocked one star off is because I wish they dimmed the lights a bit more on the inside. Obviously this is not much of an issue though at all. Definitely I recommend visiting.
name: Thurman's in Shaw

text:
This was a really fun experience for excellent, higher-end Chinese food. The service is a little spotty and a bit lacking, but the food is on point.

We had a group of six and we ordered Peking ducks, walnut shrimp, kung pao chicken, Lions head and soup dumplings. The soup dumplings and Peking duck were the stand outs for sure. The Peking duck is a large portion and so rich and tasty, plus it's served with things to make bao sandwiches - yum!

Everything is presented beautiful and is very fresh, but it is a bit expensive.
name: Private Kitchen

categories: Chinese, Restaurants, Shanghainese, American (Traditional)

text:
Great experience and good food.  Seating is by reservation only, and you must submit your order when you make the reservation.  Look on their Facebook page for the menu.  These appear to be dishes from China, and not what you find on "Americanized" menus, so they may not be familiar to you, like they were not to me.  So I did the best I could based on descriptions.

The restaurant itself is nondescript from outside.  Inside is a cozy place with about a half dozen tables of various sizes, nicely done up with actual tablecloths and cloth chair covers.  Our waitress (co-owner?) was the only worker we saw, save a few glimpses of the chef (owner?) coming out of the back for a few moments.  She was very nice the entire time, smiled a lot, spoke briefly (semi-halting English), and filled our waters frequently.  She did a good job of observing our progress on the courses, so that our plates were removed as they emptied and next course arrived quickly after we both finished the previous one - except we had a few minutes before dessert to let the dinner settle.  The serving order was different from what I would have expected in that soup dumplings (dim sum) came first, then one entree, then another entree partly through the first entree, then soup came last, followed by dessert.  Entree order was fine, but it seemed odd to have soup come so late.

Soup dumplings are what they are famous for, and are excellent if you like dim sum.  Thin and tender steamed shells (quite attractively packaged) well filled.  We had pork and crab ones.  Both were good.  Of course, you slurp out the broth inside from a small hole you make, or else it just spills onto the plate.

Chicken with chestnuts was good, too.  I'd never had chestnuts other than roasted over an open fire.  These were very tender, almost like a mushroom, but not quite that soft.

Crispy beef (not the name, but my description), was terrific.  A big mound of small bits of beef that were almost candied in a thick glaze/sauce.  Mostly savory, but with a bit of sweetness in the glaze - seemed like it was probably from honey.

House soup was a bit of a disappointment.  Broth was too bland for my preferences, and the pork meat (seemed to be pork belly) was kind of tough with the fat portions sometimes being gristly.  Bamboo shoots in the soup were large and with a very slight crunch, and pretty good.  Tofu "knots" were delicious, and plentiful.  They seem to be made from a stack of thin sheets of tofu that are cut into strips and then tied into knots.  They are not mushy at all like tofu might get in a soup, and had a pleasant snap when bit into.  They also absorbed the flavor of the broth well.

Dessert was the potted plant ice cream - A real flower was stuck in the top, with finely ground chocolate for dirt and ice cream under.  Pretty cute, fairly tasty.
name: Private Kitchen

text: I don't usually write reviews but I keep thinking about a breakfast I had last week with my grandchildren at Kingside diner in Clayton. All the food was pretty good, but the service was terrible. It was a weekday at 8:00 and no one was there, apparently, including any staff. After seating ourselves, waiting about five minutes and calling out that we were there, my eight-year-old grandson asked if he should go find some menus.  It took a long time to get our food and even longer to get our check. Our money ran out in our meter, but fortunately we did not get a ticket.  Fortunately I had cash to pay the bill so I didn't have to wait for someone to run a credit card.  I chose this restaurant because I enjoyed it in the central west end.
name: Kingside Diner

categories: Desserts, Restaurants, Diners, Food, Sandwiches, Breakfast & Brunch

text:
TL:DR - Unique concept, reservation only and must order ahead of time. Most dishes were really good and overall authentic. Very mom and pop type restaurant with mismatching glassware.

Similar to what a yelp friend said, this place is really authentic and above average Chinese food, but isn't mind-blowingly amazing (aka won't be named a top national restaurant anytime soon). The previous reviews are fairly accurate, run by a husband/wife duo, we had a mix of regular pint glasses and wine glasses for water, beer and wine is limited to whatever they just happen to have unless you ordered ahead of time, reservations only, and you need to order ahead of time either on wechat or fb messenger.

We came in with a very large party of about 16 and pretty much rented out the restaurant. I will say the wife/server was really nice and friendly often joking with us. But they had Tsingtao beer on hand, not bad, but essentially Chinese Budweiser and they had a nice red cab for wine. This was a family event so we ordered literally 16 courses family style, which was WAY too much food. But I'll mention what I thought was good to know stuff.

Shaoxing Drunken Chicken - This was a cold dish, but very unique in flavor with a subtle rice wine flavor and not something you can find a lot of places, probably my favorite dish of the night. 

Baby Pork Rib - a little sour because of the plum and too sweet for me. Just didn't really mesh well as a meat dish.

House cooked beef - probably my second favorite dish. Soy sauce braised, but still had a sugary sweet sheen on it that kept it from being transcendent.

Shrimp and Crab Roe Soup Dumpling - very seafoody taste, which could be a good thing I suppose, but I prefer the pork dumpling.

Potted Plant - Visually really appealing, it's a real flower atop oreo crumbles and we got a vanilla ice cream/strawberry yogurt mix underneath, almost wish it was mostly just ice cream.

Outside of these dishes, everything else we got was really good, flavorful and authentic. Hard to mention much about the stuff like steamed fish other than that it was good and tasted like it was supposed to for all 15 dishes.
name: Private Kitchen

text:
these guys have been my favorite part of Pan-Asia ever since the grocery store opened. Great Asian bakery selection from day one. Made me a chicken feet in wine sauce addict! Awesome BBQ pork, duck, and breads and a very balanced fu qi fei pian seasoning for their build your own option. 

I almost always get something when I go grocery shopping, and with the expansion my wish for a dining option inside has been granted! Now I also almost always choose to go shopping here so I can eat inside. 

Note: the hours are not the same as the store but I can't remember what cuz it kept changing for a while. Right now they take a break around 230-330? And close at 730p before the store does.

The selection on the dine in side is pared down, but that means all the foods come quickly. I love all the dry noodle options except the Dan Dan noodle (way overboard on the numbing). The pho was a miss - very bland broth. I usually don't order fried rice so I don't know about those. The few other non rice/noodle are ok, kind of leans toward Chinese-American but taste good - I like the garlic pork (yu xiang rou si). Usually I go for beef chow fun or Beijing style zha jiang mian, but the Taiwan style rice noodle stir fry is a new favorite. 

The only knock I have is that ever since they expanded they haven't been 100% knocking it out of the park every time like they were before. A few times, my bbq pork wasn't as seasoned, my duck was a little dry another time, my spicy chicken a little less fragrant, etc. But they seem to be working out the kinks more because it's less and less so the case and I'm hopeful. Don't be disappointed if your first visit isn't amazing and keep supporting this small local business trying to figure things out! 

I pretty much don't go anywhere else for a quick Chinese meal or groceries anymore because they make it so convenient for me!
name: China Bistro

text:

2.) Great patio. The new shade canopy is a nice touch. Not only are dogs welcome on the patio, but the owner might come out and give them a doggie biscuit or two.
3.) Great drinks. The cappelletti spritz made my whole summer.
4.) Great food. There's awesome tacos, and now there is BRUNCH.

There were a few hiccups with ordering but they smoothed that out. Band started late but when they did I looked up and it was PACCCKED! Great Jazz, drinks and Guacamole! 

A couple of warnings: the Guacamole comes in two little (side of ketchup) cups in one of those red baskets (very odd and difficult to dip your chip) and when it gets crowded the wait staff starts to harass the @$& out of you to give up your little red basket as soon as you have 10 chips left because they need them for other orders (come on guys, let's up the budget and order another stack of these). 

Great place, I'll be back!!

text:
Bobby's Place is a staple in our family as it is close to where we host most events and great for a night out. 

I was just here Saturday night for a surprise birthday party for a cousin. This was arranged in advance by her spouse and Bobby's Place had a reserved area waiting for us. They also served out a variety of appetizers very quickly and there was a server checking in on our party all evening. She was attentive and quick with orders. 

Depending on when you go there is usually a live band or a DJ. We were told there wouldn't be a live band this night, but there was one - BONUS! The band was okay, but unfortunately they seemed a bit much for the small venue. The music was so loud I couldn't hear even the person next to me and that was a bit disappointing. This is not usually the case here...

Some of us had tabs at the bar - I did. The bartenders were friendly, efficient and make a great white russian! 

They also have a nice large outdoor patio - great for nice weather (not so much on Saturday). 

Note: this bar does still allow smoking inside, so if you are a smoker - this place is for you! If not, know that going in. It does not ever get "too smoky" in my opinion, but still a good to know before going.
name: Bobby's Place

text:
Found this place by accident actually. Went in for drinks on a Thursday night and realized I just walked into Bob Plager's place!! "Number 5 in your program, Number 1 in your hearts". I was ecstatic. I saw Bob there in the back, I said hi and so wanted to ask for his autograph but felt that was not appropriate. I might go back again and ask Bob for his autograph. After all, he is an icon of the STL. Blues. 

I had a nice time. The music was good. I Did not like the margaritas though. Our waitress was very friendly and kept us content. :) A band took the stage at 10pm. I was shocked to see this place rocking on a weeknight. I would say the only negative thing was the cigarette smoke. It was not over powering but for someone that does not smoke, it was taking its toll on me. But I toughed it out. I will definitely go back and try the grill next time also.

text:
4.5 stars. Terrific fine dining experience in St. Louis. As others have mentioned, you must make a reservation and order in advance over text. Food is 5 stars, plain and simple. Soup dumplings are soft, chewy, and served elegantly with vinegar--definitely get an order or two of these. Dish of the night, though, for me was the steamed fish--it was served whole with a delicate, simple soy, ginger sauce with shredded vegetables. I'm still thinking about this fish the next day! Chinese broccoli was also delicious--simple but had an almost herbal flavor to it. Goes really well with the fish! Spicy beef was good--nice spicing with chili and lots of black pepper, but the sauce was a little sweet/goopy for my liking. Chicken with chestnuts was interesting--the chicken was nice, and the chestnuts were soft, but I don't think I'd order this dish again. In the past I've had the spare ribs, house beef, etc. But I don't remember enough about them to give a judgement. I didn't order those again, though, bc I remember the spare ribs being fatty, and the house beef fried. The Peking Duck I also ordered on a past visit, and it was out-of-this-world! Definitely a must if you're a big party. We finished with the ice cream in a plant pot which is a cool gimmick but didn't taste special at all. Probably wouldn't order again. Overall, though, the food at private kitchen is top notch. 
Non-food stuff: the restaurant is simple, small, and quiet, and I appreciated that. Definitely best for parties of 4-6. The service is...not that good. The one server is a sweet middle aged lady (the place is a couple's operation), and she is very nice, but since she is the only server, things are slooow. Don't expect to get your water refilled more than once throughout the meal, and I don't think they clear the tables of food until you leave. That's not a big deal for me, but we did have to stare a fish skeleton in the eye sockets for at least 15 minutes before (and during) dessert, which was less than ideal. This isn't the biggest gripe in the world, but it was enough to knock it down half a star, in combination with the fact that the prices are decently high. 
So, as I said, overall 4.5 stars. I would absolutely return, and plan on it next time I'm in St. Louis!!
name: Private Kitchen

Taziki was very watery and average

text:
I had a proper cheeseburger here.  Two patties, gooey cheese, nicely toasted bun.  They didn't pile a bunch of other stuff on top.  There wasn't a fancy sauce.  It cost about $8 and that's a bargain given the location.  

The patties were hard-seared on a flattop to create a little bit of crunch and caramelize the edges a bit.  The cheese was melted perfectly and even a bit stringy with each bite.  Bacon was an option but I passed.   

Fries on the side and I asked for a little bbq to use for dipping.  The fries were lightly battered and fried to a crispy, golden brown but still flaky on the inside.

The irony of this meal?  I had just ordered a grilled chicken cuban sandwich and the waitress had walked away a split second before someone delivered a cheeseburger to the next table.  I took one look at this guy's food, jumped up and caught my waitress before she entered my order so I could get the burger instead.
name: Kingside Diner

text:
Wow....I am not sure what to write here but what an experience!  A few of us met up there last night to catch up and see ADD, a great band.

First and foremost, the place is really smoky.  It is a bar so it is totally understandable.  I just mention it to you if you have issues with smoke.

Other than that, this place is priceless.  Our waitress was attentive and nice even though she had a ton of tables to manage.  The beers were cold and the mixed drinks were stiff, which is a bonus.  Personally, I do enjoy when you can actually taste the booze in a mixed drink but that is my own preference.

I cannot speak to the food but it looked like your standard bar food.

The best part of the visit was the crowd.  Boy, what a treat.  There was a guy at the bar who had a mustache drawn on his face...I couldn't make this up if I tried...

Not to mention, the Jim Beam honey liquor girls were there with a guy in a bear suit handing out free shots....  Unreal.
name: Bobby's Place

text:
It's weird to call this "Soulard Gyro" since it's not technically in Soulard! But I am in love with the owners for branching out and opening a location closer to where we live now! I stopped by on a Friday night a few weeks ago to place a carry-out order. I was pleasantly surprised to see that there were other guests in the restaurant enjoying meals. The shop itself is located in the Butler Hill shopping center right off of 55 so it's a convenient location for lots of people. Inside there are probably about 10 tables and they have a self-serve soda machine. I was able to walk right up to the counter to place my order and the guy taking my order was friendly and helpful. Once I placed my order and paid for it, they told me it would be a few minutes so I just hung out. 

This place is clearly a family owned place and I really like that! They take pride in their food and service so I can see them being around for a while! When my order was ready, the guy came out to bring it to me all packed and ready to go. Since I also ordered a slice of baklava, he came out to the dining room and went to the fridge to select a slice for me; he was awesome, because he made sure to find the biggest slice he could find, which I appreciated! 

Within 15 minutes, I was able to place an order, get my food and be on my way. This was an efficient visit and I will be back again. Their gyros are really good; I am partial to the chicken gyro which wasn't too dry and had a nice flavor to it. They top their gyros with lots of fresh ingredients and you can ask for some fresh feta too! Give them a try!
name: Soulard Gyro

text:
Food was amazing and we're already planning out what we'll be eating next! We read about this hidden gem and couldn't wait to try it, and we're glad we did. It sits inside of Pan-Asia grocery store. I personally have not eaten Chinese food in this area because it all seems to be the same "Americanized" version but this place is different!

Plenty of seating available and when we ordered at the counter the guy was very helpful with suggestions. Food came out quick and when I saw this big bowl of beef soup my initial response was "Omg that looks delicious!" which the guy replied "I know." lol. The other dish we ordered was #19 a thick noodle stir fry of some kind, also very tasty! I forgot to take a picture as we were super excited to dig into the soup. 

Prices were cheap in our opinion - $9.99 for both dishes and the portion sizes were generous! We couldn't finish and we both have hearty appetites. 

Hope you give it a try and post your pics so we know what to get next time! :)
name: China Bistro

text:
Gotta love a place who gets its namesake from Bobby Plager, one of the most charismatic and beloved people to ever wear the Blue Note. 

This place gives you everything. You can get cheap, fast lunch specials guaranteed in under 15 mins as well as daily specials. They run some good drink specials as well, including cheap pitchers on Thursdays. They also feature the 40 oz Busch bottles, which I am partial to. Rotating craft beer taps were a nice touch for a bar in this area. I've eaten here a handful of times and its always tasty... steak sandwich, pizza, wings.... all very good. Its bar food, but its good bar food. They make their own wing sauce which is tangier than most. 

They do allow smoking, but theres a patio also. Lots of TVs, juke box and a few bar games such as Golden Tee... you may even see Bobby running around in there from time to time.
name: Bobby's Place

text: Great dive bar! If you love bar food, beer, and hockey, you can't go wrong. I recently stopped by this place for the first time for a St. Patty's Day meal and to watch the Sabres/Blues game. Felisha was our server and she was amazing!!! The restaurant was packed and she was the only server on at the time. We never once felt looked over or forgotten about. I've never felt so taken care of by a server before. We got a few buckets of beer and she always seemed to swing by just as we ran out to get us another one. Food was alright but we weren't expecting a 5 star meal. Overall, a great experience. I took off one star just because it is a smoking bar. As long as you're cool with that, it's a great local bar that I'm happy to support! Go Sabres!
name: Bobby's Place

text:
A restaurant within a market, you know there is authenticity cooking.  

I noticed there was a display of buns that brought back childhood memories and growing up in LA, it was at my disposal: bbq pork, pineapple bun, and the red bean bun are my "day-ones."  Ask Jenny, the cashier, I literally always buy at least one savory and one sweet bun and that is just my portion!  They make it fresh, it's an open kitchen, and you can literally see them baking buns or cooking up an order for their customers.  Also on display, is roast duck and bbq pork.  It would make dinner easy if you wanted to order half a pound of duck/pork or a pound if you have many mouths to feed.

You can dine there or take out.  Amidst everything going on with Covid-19, we have gotten use to taking food home.  We come here often and I can continue updating this for you all and know you are not making a mistake to choose to support China Bistro or Pan Asia. 

Service: amazing!  The cooks and cashiers are very friendly.  service is quick and you will be in and out in no time! 

Food: always and I mean always consistent.  We usually order the pho beef bowls (best, seriously the best, pho in STL) however this time around, we ordered egg noodle soup with roast duck.  On the menu it says plain noodle soup and you can add a protein so we specifically asked if we can have egg noodle.  We also ordered the stir-fry bok choy with shitake mushrooms and garlic, legit!  We also ordered a Young Chow Fried Rice or Combination fried rice, come on!  Best combo fried rice ever!  We had a friend over that evening and he even said wow!  That is really really good!  We love protein so we order the fried rice with extra chicken. 

Hope this helps make your belly, your heart, and your taste buds dance!  

Lots of love.
P&J
name: China Bistro

text:
Stopped in the other day for lunch and had an excellent classic gyro and classic hummus. Gyro had tons of meat and plenty of tzatziki. The pita was soft, fresh, and warm out of the oven.

Overall, price was very reasonable and after filling up, I left with enough leftovers that I ate the rest for dinner and was still full, which is a rarity.

One note: The spicy tzatziki is well-named. I enjoyed the spice level, but I would suggest anyone not comfortable with fairly spicy food either try the regular tzatziki or ask for some on the side first.

They have a great draft selection with a decent group of beer and wine. The have an industrial pipe shelving bar with some pipe light fixtures along the wall. It's imitate but casual. 

The service felt better and overall just a great upgrade. I'll be back for sure.

text: I've eaten at China Bistro twice now.  It's the food counter inside the Pan-Asia Supermarket.  On my first visit I ordered dandan noodles.  The portion was huge but I took about 4 bites of these and I couldn't eat anymore.  The mala (spicy and numbing Chinese sauce) was overwhelming!  I was uncomfortable and my lips were simultaneously numb and on fire! I ignored the lady when she said "very spicy" and said to myself, of course dandan noodles will be spicy. Too much for me! On my second visit I ordered #7 Singapore Rice Noodles.  This is typically called Singapore chow mei fun. It's a thin rice noodle with curry, egg, shrimp, and pork.  This was delicious and a large portion! The food is great here, the prices are extremely reasonable (all around $10 per dish), and the portions are very generous. Great place to eat before you shop the market. I'm looking forward to working my way through this menu! I will be back!
name: China Bistro

text: Bobby's Place is GREAT!  There are very few smoking bars left and one can even enjoy a cigar.  The waitresses/bartender are the BEST!!  Always fast and very friendly service.  Food is upscale bar food but the WINGS are the best in town. The cooks are truly "keepers".  They have a tiny kitchen and get the food out fast.  The ppl who complained about the smoke should not go, or not complain.  There are plenty of non-smoking restaurants around, so go there and DON'T complain.  My husband and I love the place and frequent often.
name: Bobby's Place

text: From what we've found, this is the best pho in our neighborhood! We're excited to explore the rest of the menu, but the pho is so good that it's hard to pass up when we repeat visits. But at least when we see other people ordering different dishes, the food all looks and smells delicious! The staff are also friendly and prompt, and the prices just can't be beat! Obviously, in the middle of a supermarket, if you're vying for ambiance, it's not unpleasant, but it's not a restaurant setting--like I said, it's counter service to dine in or take out inside a supermarket. But the food is honestly delicious, and if you like, you can take the food to-go and eat in any surroundings you want! We'll keep coming back!
name: China Bistro

He came alone and only drank water but every waitress there stopped by to get something from him. He kept scratching/rubbing his pocket (breaking up powder) and then folded things into a newspaper on the table.  Whoever the tall heavier woman was is not just failing as a waitress but even more as a distributor for the dealer because if she hadn't been so rude and just brought our beer we wouldn't have noticed her blatantly engaging in illegal behavior.

text:
Service: 3 Stars 
Pho Broth: 3.5 Stars 
Beef: 2 Stars 
Value 4 Stars 
Total: 3.125 Stars
Would I Return? Yes

I love Pan-Asian Market and was excited to try China Bistro, the food stall inside the market. I've only been once and ordered the "Vietnamese Beef Noodle Bowl" AKA pho tai. 

You order and pay at the counter then someone brings you your food. Beverages, condiments and the like are self-service. I didn't see a place for trash or to put dirty dishes, so I left those at the table when finished. The people were friendly, but three stars seems appropriate for a partially self-service situation. 

The menu seems to specialize in noodle bowl and soup-type dishes. They also have a limited number of what appear to be Peking ducks hanging in a case, as well as a selection of cakes and buns. I ordered a large bowl of pho with beef. 

The broth was light-colored and not too greasy. It was on the sweeter side than I prefer, I think the cinnamon and star anise were dominant, but I'm no expert on Vietnamese flavors. The beef was not the thin, raw slices that many places offer, which cooks in the hot broth. These were more like strips of fully cooked meat. The bowl was accompanied by rhe standard plate of bean sprouts, cilantro, basil and lime. Overall, it was a pretty good bowl. Not the best ever, but above average to my taste. 

The prices were very reasonable. It was a good experience, especially adding in the chance to browse the market or do some shopping before or after lunch.
name: China Bistro

text: I just want to cry when I see General Tso's chicken & other Americanized Chinese dishes offered at a joint like this.  Yes, it is true.  There's an entire page in the menu dedicated to Americanized Chinese dishes.  Just only 6 tables inside this tiny place.  The wife I assume serves & gets the food, while the husband I assume cooks.  I agree with previous review about the Peking Duck being delish.  However, & a big however, I was told by the wife that the duck must be ordered 2 days in advance.  He makes it from scratch.  Super cool.  The menu is in Chinese for the most part.  The food was just bleh for me.  Very bland tasting IMHO.  Maybe it was because we (my parents & I) didn't order the right things.  The only things that I did like were the duck soup (made from the bones in a white soup base) & the Peking Duck with steamed pancakes.  For about 5 dishes, the price of this dinner came to about $70.  This place doesn't take all credit cards (I forget which ones).  I don't know if I'll ever come back here again.
name: Private Kitchen

text:
My wife and I moved to Shaw at the end of June.  Since then Thurman's has basically been closed the whole time as it has transitioned ownership.  Last night, we decided to walk to the corner of Thurman and Shenandoah (downtown Shaw) for dinner with our 10 month old baby. 

We've been following the announcements on social media as the new Thurman's has added to its menu.  First it was just the drinks.  Then came salads.  Now, they offer burgers, fries, chicken sandwiches, chili, and many entree salads.

When we arrived, we planned to sit outside on the patio where there are long communal tables. The only problem was there were smokers, so with the baby we headed inside.  The music playing was all jazz and MoTown. We grabbed a high top table. I went to the bar to order drinks, a glass of cabernet for her and a local IPA for me. All the draft selections were from local craft breweries: Urban Chestnut, Civil Life, Four Hands, O'Fallon, Schlafly, and Griesedieck's.  In bottles were macro swill and a fascinating list of Belgian beers, including a Flander's Red sour.  The selection isn't a long list yet, but I'm very impressed so far.

We both had cheese burgers with a basket of fries to share.  My wife also had the caesar salad.  All the food was tasty and right on bar for a neighborhood bar.  The burgers were simple and juicy without pretension.

We're very excited to have a new food option down the block. I'm sure we'll be regulars at Thurman's.
name: Thurman's in Shaw

text:
Perhaps I'm just too pedestrian to understand he grand allure and mystique of this restaurant or perhaps there's been so much build up, I had higher expectations. Whatever the case, If I needed a nosh, I'm going to stick with my own private kitchen instead of this one.
Granted, my friend scored the reservations (which I hear are difficult to get) at 5:30pm after much instruction about texting and not calling. Again - I love the mystery. The only time she could snag was 5:30pm because they were booked otherwise. We were there a little before 5:30pm and the place was empty other than the proprietors (totally my assumption - but they gave out a lot of orders so I think it's a pretty good guess). She was dressed in sweatpants. Let that sink in. Sweat. Pants. I'm already not feeling this place. There were only 6 tables in the restaurant. We were promptly seated and our food just started to arrive - in no kind of order - it just shows up. Side note - they insist on patrons to place their order prior to the meal via email. Portions are big enough to share. The soup is A LOT. 
Again, just the one server and her sweatpants serving the other two tables. One was a party of eight. We rarely got checked on and water was scarce. Once you're done with the meal - out you go. She did give some boxes for our leftovers - but we boxed it ourselves. The food was fine. The dumplings were definitely the high point. I've had better Chinese elsewhere that wasn't as pretentious.
name: Private Kitchen

text: Walked in and was immediately turned off.  People were smoking all around.  Disgusting.  The food, not impressed. I ordered the steak sandwich and side salad.  Salad was the best part. I had wanted a vinaigrette dressing, but apparently that's too classy for this place.  They only had 3 different salad dressings, so I was forced to pick  ranch.  The only flavor on the sandwich was the horseradish.  The meat was bland, bland, bland.  The "server" had no idea how to wait tables.  There were 4 people at our table.  Took her 2 trips to bring 4 drinks.  Took her 3 trips to bring everyone's order.  At the end of the meal I asked the "server" for a box for the other 1/2 of my sandwich.  Even though it wasn't the best I never let food go to waste.  Sit there a while talking and waiting and this dumb little girl basically asked us if we were leaving. I glared at her and said I'm waiting for the box that I requested.  Maybe if this place spent more time hiring wait staff with talent and a brain instead of who looks good in a bra and mini skirt, they might actually be crowded on a Sat night.  If the line hadn't been so long at Sugarfire, would have dined there.  Save your money and time.  This dive is not worth it!
name: Bobby's Place

text:
Brought my partner for her bday dinner this evening and had a wonderful time! 

I must say, I'm equally shocked and not surprised by negative reviews surrounding covid protocols. Some people are just determined to be unhappy. And since you can't say it, I'll say it for you: "The customer is NOT always right".  From one industry professional to another, don't the haters get you down. Karma's a bitch 

Back to our experience: we were greeted by two, a trainee with a shadow. I believe they introduced themselves as "M.L." Or maybe... Em Elle? Anyway, they were wonderful. And the shadow trainer was present but did not enter the conversation unless needed, creating a good boost of confidence for the trainee. Both had great recommendations on cocktails, apps, pizza, entrees and wine. We felt very welcome. 

To start off we both got a Black Manhattan, it was so smooth. The booze sort of snuck up on us. (Not to insinuate it wasn't boozy, we felt it ). On the servers' recommendation we moved on to the Calimari. OMFG - wow. Never had a Calimari without a dipping sauce before, but it did not need it, giardiniera  was fried in with it and it was bursting with complimentary flavors. 

For entrees, bday lady got the eggplant parm and we split a pizza. She said the texture was a little weird for her, but the flavor was awesome. Neither of us are red-meat eaters, so we got the sausage-ricotta-giardiniera pizza, minus the sausage. We also splurged on a side of the house made hot honey. It was upscale flavor town, like guy fieri in a tux. seriously tho, it was yum. 

The ambiance was totally our cup of tea. I mean, drinking manhattans while our four year old is safe at home with grandma while listening to beastie boys and biggie smalls and eating bomb-ass pizza.... you had us at Beastie Boys. 

We'll be back.
name: O+O Pizza

text: I am a regular here as it is close to my house and love this bar! However when it gets busy do not expect great service, it takes about 15-20 mins for someone to come check up on you so we normally have to go hunt them down which doesnt bug us for people who are new that are with us it makes them pretty mad. Also if you are in a big group keep an eye on your tab/ bank account. My card normally gets run twice when I come for some reason. The food is great though and the happy hr has really good specials! Also a good place to go on friday for ladies night ($2 wines, wells, and domestics) and wednesday for $1 well night!

I wish I could give this place negative stars.

We ordered two mixed drinks plus a pitcher of Budweiser, the server had to come back to ask if we wanted a pitcher or bucket, and what of. Then she charged us for a bucket and gave us Bud Light. The mixed drinks tasted like fruit punch and orange juice, I really don't believe there was any booze in the drinks.  There was so much smoke in the joint that I think I might have cancer already. The band was agonizingly loud and did a terrible job on their covers. Don't go. Please. For me, don't go to this bar.

The gyros we picked up were good. All three were bursting with fillings and sauces. I appreciated the choice of a spicy tzatziki.

Service was fast and friendly. The employee answered all of our questions and was accommodating about substitutions.

I have to ding them on the side of hummus we ordered, though. First, it was a different flavor than we ordered. Secondly, and more importantly, it only had about two tablespoons of hummus in the container. I'm used to places giving you a ton of hummus; the amount we received was pitiful. Definitely not worth $5.

text:
Prices are affordable and portions are generous! However, the food wasn't too impressive. We ordered the beef stew thick noodle soup, the Beijing signature noodle, and the dan dan mian. I think a big issue for me for all three noodle dishes was that I wasn't a big fan of the noodles themselves. They just had a very flat texture, and they lacked bounce/chew? It's hard to describe!

#20. Beef stew thick noodle soup was a pretty standard beef noodle soup. The beef itself was quite tasty, but the soup was rather bland. This was my least favorite dish.

#19. Beijing signature noodles, aka zha jiang mian, was the best of the three dishes, but overall not worth returning to get. The name of the dish on the English menu is rather unrevealing, but it's essentially a meat, veggie and bean paste mix. I was a bit disappointed at first, only because the picture on the menu looked like jajangmyeon, which is the Korean equivalent of these bean paste noodles. Those are thicker, saucier and sweeter than the Chinese version, which can be less saucy and the taste of bean paste is usually stronger. This dish definitely could have used more sauce, since the sauce to noodle ratio was a rather low.

#18. Dan dan mian. The spice did overwhelm the other flavors of the sauce though. I've had better!

text: One of my go to's in my hood. Service is always super friendly, whether for pickup or dining in. I've had a variety of items here but I find myself always coming back to the burger. It's the best freaking $10 you'll probably spend this year. Pearl vodka is a close 2'nd (look it up, it's local ). Double patty, add bacon, american cheese. Done. Go to sleep. That's all your life needs. You're welcome. Oh and slather your burger and fries with ketchup. Lift to mouth and destroy. Rinse and repeat.

text: Ordered Veggie Hash with eggs over medium and side of toast. Place was nearly empty. Was served eggs with hard yolk and cold toast. When I sent it back the waitress told me "this is how we serve over medium".  Pretty sure I've ordered over medium several thousand times before and have a pretty good sense of how they're supposed to be cooked. Rather than engage her in a debate I walked out. Very disappointing.

text:
Four star bar, but I'm removing a star because it's a smoking bar. I don't like the smell of cigarettes. It's a blue collar crowd. 

Cool place. Bobby's is a sports bar that focuses on hockey. However, if you come here to watch a game, grab a table. The bar is in the center of the room, but the TV's are spread along the perimeter of the restaurant. You don't have a good view of a TV if you sit at the bar.

Great happy hour specials. I went here on a Friday and from 4:00-8:00, they had $2 domestic drafts and 1/2 price appetizers. Bobby's has pub grub, but their menu is broader than a lot of sports bars. The server recommended burgers, wings and catfish nuggets. I ordered a cheeseburger and tater tots. The burger was good; the tots were great! I can see where the catfish nuggets would be good since they bread their food by hand.

The server was a sweetheart. She was patient with my many questions. I wish she could have been quicker to check on my table, but it was a busy Friday night and she was covering most of the bar. She did a good job under the circumstances. The bartenders and servers at Bobby's are all female and they are cute.
name: Bobby's Place

text:
ok,  BEST CHINESE FOOD IN ST. LOUIS. 
simple, that's it. 

By all means, I would love to hear if someone has a recommendation that is as good, or better.  I would love to be informed of where I can find a spot to eat Chinese food (or Asian Cuisine for that matter), Nearly as Good, As Good, or Even Better.

Their BBQ Pork - the closest amazing flavor's to the Char Siu BBQ pork that I have enjoyed in Hawaii

Threw down the challenge, and I hope I can be proven wrong.
Being informed of a new place to visit would be an absolute treat.

-Their BBQ Pork ... Amazing. Best in St. Louis - no one comes close
-Their Singapore Noodles - Wonderful. Others may come close, but this place has my favorite.
-Their Pork Fried Rice - Incredible - My Opinion, because it is made with the best BBQ Pork you will find in St. Louis
-Their Dan Dan Noodles - not for the faint of heart, alot of heat (and I am the faint of heart) I enjoyed it, but %#$! it was hot to me (maybe not others, but it was very hot for me)

they probably have a host of more amazing dishes, but its such a treat for me to go there, I do not go too far off the road map of dishes I am familiar with

again.

BEST CHINESE FOOD RESTAURANT IN ST. LOUIS
name: China Bistro

text:
Pretty sure their chopsticks covers still say "Private Chicken" on them, but nobody really GAF and I've been taking my family here for years. One of the best kept secrets among the chinese-food gourmands in STL, and one of my favorite places to impress visitors with (after all the bbq and Ted Drewes).

**Important: Call/Wechat/FB Message them to reserve a spot and order from their FB menu before coming! It's a very small family restaurant run by only three people with just one chef, so they need to prep all the supplies for every reservation.**

Food: I lost count on everything I ordered from the menu/requested off the menu over the years, but every time my party (small or large) left with happy tummies. Some highlights:
- Order/request any of the pure crab roe dishes
- Crab-only XLB (they also own Soup Dumplings STL next door), the crab-only XLB is my absolute favorite and great value compared to what you'd get elsewhere.
- If you order the peking duck, request the Chinese crepes instead of buns to go with them
- Squirrel fish is excellent
- Shrimp with sweet chili sauce sounds generic but is gorgeous in presentation, comes with unexpected textures and bursts with flavors
- Skip the lobster though unless it's a mandatory part of your diet. It's not bad, just something you can get easily elsewhere while you save room for the other creations from this kitchen.

It's not cheap, but it's the most delicately authentic Chinese food you'll have in St. Louis. 5 stars for being a gem.
name: Private Kitchen
